payload.title: Reorganize Core Modules Architecture
payload.description: Refactor the architecture of @gitgov/core to align with the blueprints. This includes creating specific modules for crypto, factories, and stores, and removing legacy files from the 'schemas' directory.
payload.notes: Completed as a prerequisite for the `identity_adapter` implementation. This effort establishes the canonical directory structure for domain logic.

payload.title: Sanitize and Fix Type System
payload.description: Fixed the type generation system and established a robust type architecture. This involved correcting build scripts, creating a manual type definition layer in `src/models` for complex types, and ensuring all auto-generated types in `src/types` are correct.
payload.notes: This was a critical step to eliminate over 50 TypeScript compilation errors and enable type-safe development.

payload.title: Improve and Standardize Utility Modules
payload.description: Refactored and improved core utility modules, primarily id_generator.ts. Absorbed logic from legacy files, created specific functions per entity protocol (generateActorId, generateTaskId), and implemented robust parsing and validation functions.
payload.notes: Unit tests were created for the new id_generator module to ensure its correctness.

payload.title: Sanitize Build and Test Environment

payload.notes: This effort resulted in a stable codebase where `pnpm build` completes successfully, unblocking future development.

payload.title: Add test checksum test coverage for TaskRecord
payload.description:
Expand the test suite in `crypto/checksum.test.ts` to cover the `TaskRecord` type.

- WHEN calculatePayloadChecksum is invoked on two `TaskRecord` objects with identical data but different key order, THE SYSTEM SHALL produce the exact same checksum.
- WHEN a `TaskRecord` payload is created for the test, IT SHALL be a complete and valid object according to `task_record_schema.yaml`.

payload.title: Implement DiagramGenerator core class with caching and validation
payload.description:
Implement the main DiagramGenerator class that orchestrates diagram generation. Includes:

- Core logic for analyzing relationships and generating diagrams
- Performance optimization with Map-based caching
- Input validation and error handling
- Cache key generation for efficient lookups
- Integration with RelationshipAnalyzer and MermaidRenderer
- DiagramMetrics integration for monitoring

This is the central orchestrator class that coordinates all other components.
payload.notes: Central orchestrator class. Must be implemented first as other components depend on its interfaces.

payload.title: Implement MermaidRenderer class with syntax generation and validation
payload.description:
Implement the MermaidRenderer class responsible for generating valid Mermaid syntax. Includes:

- Main rendering method with input sanitization and output validation
- Node syntax generation with XSS prevention through sanitization
- Edge syntax generation with relationship validation
- Color scheme application with safe CSS generation
- Content sanitization to prevent injection attacks
- Mermaid syntax validation to ensure valid output

This class transforms RelationshipGraph objects into valid Mermaid diagram code.
payload.notes: Responsible for Mermaid syntax generation. Depends on RelationshipAnalyzer output. Security-focused with sanitization.

payload.title: Implement RelationshipAnalyzer for graph analysis and hierarchy building
payload.description:
Implement the RelationshipAnalyzer class responsible for analyzing entity relationships and building hierarchical structures. Includes:

- Epic task detection using tag analysis (epic:* pattern)
- Hierarchy building with circular dependency prevention
- Graph analysis and validation
- Node and edge construction for DiagramGraph
- Assignment detection from FeedbackRecords
- Relationship mapping between Cycles and Tasks

This class provides the intelligence for understanding entity relationships and building the graph structure.
payload.notes: Core intelligence component. Must implement circular dependency detection. Required by DiagramGenerator.

payload.title: Implement ContentSanitizer for security and input validation
payload.description:
Implement the ContentSanitizer class responsible for security and input validation. Includes:

- Node title sanitization (remove HTML tags, quotes, length limits)
- Node ID sanitization for valid Mermaid identifiers
- Status validation against allowed values
- Graph sanitization (filter invalid nodes/edges)
- XSS prevention for diagram content
- DoS protection through length limits

This class ensures all diagram content is safe and valid before rendering.
payload.notes: Security-critical component. Must prevent XSS and injection attacks. Used by MermaidRenderer.

payload.title: Implement DiagramMetrics for performance monitoring and caching
payload.description:
Implement the DiagramMetrics class for performance monitoring and cache management. Includes:

- Cache hit/miss tracking for performance optimization
- Generation time recording and averaging
- Memory leak prevention (limit stored measurements)
- Cache hit ratio calculation
- Performance metrics reporting
- Quality metrics for diagram generation

This class provides observability into diagram generation performance and helps optimize the system.
payload.notes: Performance monitoring component. Lower priority as it's supportive functionality. Can be implemented after core functionality.

payload.title: Implement File System Integration with Chokidar for auto-regeneration
payload.description:
Implement the File System Integration layer using Chokidar for automatic diagram regeneration. Includes:

- DiagramFileWatcher class with debounced regeneration
- File system monitoring for .gitgov/ changes
- Watch path configuration and filtering
- Debounced regeneration to prevent multiple triggers
- Auto-commit integration for Git workflows
- Error handling and recovery for file operations

This component enables automatic diagram updates when GitGovernance entities change.
payload.notes: Integration layer for automatic updates. Depends on core DiagramGenerator being functional. Future migration to Event Bus planned.

payload.title: Implement custom error classes and validation utilities
payload.description:
Implement custom error classes and validation utilities for the diagram generator module. Includes:

- ValidationError class for input validation failures
- CircularDependencyError class for graph validation
- RenderingError class for Mermaid syntax issues
- MermaidValidator utility for syntax validation
- Input validation helpers and type guards
- Error message standardization

These utilities provide robust error handling and validation across all diagram generator components.
payload.notes: Foundation utilities. Should be implemented early as other components depend on these error classes and validators.

payload.title: Implement gitgov diagram CLI command
payload.description:
Implement the complete `gitgov diagram` CLI command following the diagram_command.md specification. This command provides an intuitive interface for generating and managing workflow diagrams. Includes:

1. **generate subcommand**: Manual diagram generation with filtering and output options
2. **watch subcommand**: Automatic regeneration on file changes with debouncing
3. **validate subcommand**: Diagram coherence validation and problem detection
4. **config subcommand**: Configuration management for diagram preferences
5. **Git integration**: Hooks for automatic regeneration on commits
6. **Progressive complexity**: Simple defaults with advanced options available

This command democratizes workflow visibility by providing both simple one-shot generation and advanced automation features for development teams.
payload.notes: This CLI command depends on the DiagramGenerator module being implemented first. It provides the user-facing interface for all diagram functionality and includes Git integration for seamless workflow automation.

The primary goal is to improve the default usability of the diagram by excluding historical entities. By default, all records with status 'archived' should be filtered out. 2. Running `gitgov diagram --show-archived` must include all entities, including those with status 'archived'.

payload.title: Diagram: Use task title for node labels
payload.description:

- File: `packages/core/src/diagram_generator/relationship_analyzer.ts`
- Method: `buildNodes`

1. The `buildNodes` method in `RelationshipAnalyzer` must be updated to use `task.title`.
2. The `extractTitleFromDescription` helper method should be removed as it will no longer be needed.
3. The final generated diagram must display the content of the `TaskRecord.title` field for all task nodes.

payload.title: Implement author/lastModifier enrichment in IndexerAdapter
payload.description:
# Implement EnrichedTaskRecord with Complete Intelligence Layer

## Context

IndexerAdapter blueprint (indexer_adapter.md) defines complete EnrichedTaskRecord specification with relationships, metrics, derivedState, and release fields. Current implementation only has basic enrichment. DashboardTUI needs author/lastModifier and full context to display intelligent task views.

## Scope

Implement complete EnrichedTaskRecord according to EARS 25-48 specification.

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Signature Utilities

Create packages/core/src/utils/signature_utils.ts with 5 generic helper functions:
- extractAuthor (actorId + timestamp)
- extractLastModifier (actorId + timestamp)
- extractContributors (array of keyIds)
- extractLastSignatureTimestamp
- getSignatureCount

Requirements:
- Generic: works with EmbeddedMetadataRecord<T>
- Graceful degradation: return undefined for missing signatures (EARS 47-48)
- Performance: O(1) except extractContributors O(n)
- Comprehensive tests with mock GitGovRecords

### Phase 2: Enrichment Core

Implement complete enrichTaskRecord() in packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/index.ts with 11-step algorithm:
1. Activity metadata (lastUpdated, lastActivityType, recentActivity)
2. Signatures (author, lastModifier with timestamps)
3. Assignments (assignedTo from feedback)
4. Dependencies (dependsOn, blockedBy with typed references)
5. Cycles (all cycles as array with id+title)
6. Metrics (executionCount, blockingFeedbackCount, openQuestionCount)
7. Time to resolution (for done tasks)
8. Release info (isReleased, lastReleaseVersion from changelogs)
9. Derived states (isStalled, isAtRisk, needsClarification, isBlockedByDependency)
10. Health score (0-100 using multi-factor algorithm)
11. Time in current stage (days)

Key Details:
- Use signature_utils helpers for author/lastModifier
- Filter completed tasks in dependsOn/blockedBy
- Preserve typed references with prefixes (task:, pr:, issue:, file:, url:)
- relationships.cycles is ARRAY (task.cycleIds is plural)
- Health algorithm: status 30%, feedback 30%, executions 20%, time 20%

### Phase 3: Integration

Update generateIndex() in indexer_adapter/index.ts:
- Call enrichTaskRecord() for all tasks with Promise.all() (parallel)
- Include enrichedTasks field in IndexData
- Keep tasks raw field for backward compatibility
- Verify IndexData structure matches blueprint spec

### Phase 4: Testing

Create 24 new tests in indexer_adapter.test.ts covering EARS 25-48:
- EARS 25-26: Activity metadata + IndexData inclusion
- EARS 27-33: Advanced field calculation (metrics, release)
- EARS 34-35: Signature extraction with helpers
- EARS 36-40: Complete relationships (assignedTo, dependencies, cycles)
- EARS 41-46: DerivedState enrichment (health, flags)
- EARS 47-48: Graceful degradation for missing signatures

Add performance tests:
- Enrichment completes <500ms for 100 tasks
- Snapshot test for index.json structure

### Phase 5: Dashboard Integration

Update DashboardTUI.tsx to consume enrichedTasks:
- Replace indexData.tasks with indexData.enrichedTasks
- Display author, lastModifier with timestamps
- Display health score with color coding
- Display dependencies (blockedBy, dependsOn)
- Graceful fallback if enrichedTasks unavailable

### Phase 6: Validation

Actions:
- Run all existing tests (18 must still pass)
- Run new tests (24 EARS 25-48 must pass)
- Regenerate index.json with gitgov indexer
- Verify enrichedTasks field present in index.json
- Verify blueprint indexer_adapter.md remains accurate

## Acceptance Criteria

- Phase 1: signature_utils.ts + tests created and passing
- Phase 2: enrichTaskRecord() implements complete 11-step spec
- Phase 3: generateIndex() includes enrichedTasks in IndexData
- Phase 4: 24 new tests (EARS 25-48) passing + performance tests
- Phase 5: DashboardTUI displays enriched data with fallback
- Phase 6: All 42 tests passing (18 existing + 24 new)
- Phase 6: index.json regenerated with enrichedTasks field
- Blueprint indexer_adapter.md remains accurate

## References

- Blueprint: packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/adapters/indexer_adapter.md
- EARS Specification: Section 4.1.1-4.1.2 (EARS 25-48)
- Types: packages/core/src/types/embedded.types.ts
- Current implementation: packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/index.ts
- Dashboard: packages/cli/src/components/dashboard/DashboardTUI.tsx

payload.title: Fix status command duplicate display
payload.description:
**BUG FIX**: Personal status view (`gitgov status`) shows duplicate tasks while global view (`gitgov status --all`) works correctly.

## 🐛 Problem Description

The personal status view displays the same task multiple times:
```
✅ Mi Trabajo (2 tasks)
  ⚡ [active] 1758544872-task-complete-vim-style-navigation-in-dashboard-tui - Add task selection to dashboard 🟡
  ⚡ [active] 1758544872-task-complete-vim-style-navigation-in-dashboard-tui - Add task selection to dashboard 🟡
```

However, only 1 task actually exists (confirmed via `gitgov task list --status active --json`).

## 🔍 Investigation Results

- ✅ **No real duplication**: Only 1 task exists with that ID
- ✅ **Cache is valid**: `gitgov indexer --validate-only` passes
- ✅ **Global view works**: `gitgov status --all` shows correct count
- ❌ **Personal view has bug**: Shows same task multiple times

## 🎯 Root Cause Analysis

**Suspected Location**: `packages/cli/src/commands/status/status-command.ts`
**Suspected Issue**: Personal task filtering logic duplicates tasks when:
- Multiple FeedbackRecords exist for the same task assignment
- Task filtering doesn't deduplicate properly
- Rendering logic processes the same task multiple times

## 📋 Implementation Requirements

### **COMPONENT 1: Investigate Personal Task Filtering**

Examine the personal status logic:
```typescript
// In StatusCommand, find the personal task filtering
// Look for logic that filters tasks assigned to current actor
// Check if it's creating duplicates from multiple assignments
```

### **COMPONENT 2: Fix Duplication Logic**

Add deduplication to personal task filtering:
```typescript
// Ensure tasks are deduplicated by ID before display
const uniqueTasks = tasks.filter((task, index, self) => 
  index === self.findIndex(t => t.id === task.id)
);
```

### **COMPONENT 3: Verify Assignment Logic**

Check FeedbackRecord processing:
- Multiple assignment FeedbackRecords for same task shouldn't duplicate display
- Task should appear once regardless of assignment history

## 🧪 Testing Requirements

### **Manual Testing**
1. **Create task with multiple assignments**
2. **Run `gitgov status`** → Should show task only once
3. **Run `gitgov status --all`** → Should match personal count
4. **Verify with JSON output** → Confirm no duplication

### **Edge Cases**
- Task with multiple assignment FeedbackRecords
- Task assigned and reassigned to same actor
- Task with mixed assignment types

## 📁 Files to Investigate

1. **`packages/cli/src/commands/status/status-command.ts`**
   - Personal task filtering logic
   - FeedbackRecord processing for assignments

2. **Related StatusAdapter methods**
   - Task filtering by actor
   - Assignment processing logic

## 🎯 Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ **No Duplication**: Personal status shows each task only once
2. ✅ **Consistent Counts**: Personal and global views show same task counts
3. ✅ **Assignment Logic**: Multiple assignments don't cause duplication
4. ✅ **Performance**: Fix doesn't impact status command performance

## 🚨 Priority: Medium

This is a visual bug that doesn't affect functionality but impacts user experience and trust in the system.

payload.title: Enhance task command help with step-by-step workflow guide
payload.description:
**ENHANCEMENT**: Improve `gitgov task --help` with comprehensive step-by-step workflow guide, real examples, and complete command coverage for AI assistant consultation.

## 🎯 Problem Statement

Current help is too technical and doesn't explain the **complete workflow**. Users (including AI assistants like @gitgov) get confused about:
- What each status means (draft → review → ready → active → done)
- Which commands to use in which order
- What happens at each transition
- When to assign tasks and auto-assignment behavior
- How to handle rejections and cancellations
- Real examples of the complete flow

## 📋 Current Help Issues

**Current output is technical but not educational:**
```
submit [options] <taskId>         Transition TaskRecord from draft to review with workflow validation
approve|ap [options] <taskId>     Approve TaskRecord with signature validation and auto-transition
```

**Missing critical information:**
- ❌ No step-by-step workflow explanation
- ❌ No status transition diagram
- ❌ No real examples with actual commands
- ❌ No explanation of what each status means
- ❌ No guidance on "what should I do next?"
- ❌ Missing reject/cancel commands in workflow
- ❌ No assignment workflow explanation
- ❌ No auto-assignment behavior documentation

## 🎯 Enhanced Help Design

### **SECTION 1: Complete Workflow Overview**
```
TASK WORKFLOW (GitGovernance Default Methodology):
  draft → review → ready → active → done → archived

  Step 1: Create task           → gitgov task new "Fix login bug"
  Step 2: Submit for review     → gitgov task submit <taskId>
  Step 3: Approve definition    → gitgov task approve <taskId>
  Step 4: Start work            → gitgov task activate <taskId> (manual, auto-assigns if unassigned)
          [FUTURE: Automatic]   → gitgov exec add <taskId> --result "Started work"
  Step 5: Complete task         → gitgov task complete <taskId>

REJECTION/CANCELLATION PATHS:
  review → discarded            → gitgov task reject <taskId>
  ready/active → discarded      → gitgov task cancel <taskId>
```

### **SECTION 2: Status Meanings**
```
STATUS MEANINGS:
  draft     - Planning: Define requirements, write specs
  review    - Review: Validate requirements before approval  
  ready     - Approved: Ready to start implementation
  active    - Working: Currently being implemented
  done      - Complete: Implementation finished
  archived  - Final: Task completed and documented
  discarded - Cancelled: Task rejected or cancelled
```

### **SECTION 3: Assignment Workflow**
```
ASSIGNMENT (Flexible - Any Status):
  Manual Assignment:
    gitgov task assign <taskId> --to human:developer    # At any status
    gitgov task assign <taskId> --to agent:backend      # Reassignment allowed
    
  Auto-Assignment (Smart Behavior):
    - When someone activates unassigned task → auto-assigns to them
    - When someone starts exec on unassigned task → auto-assigns to them
    - Multiple people can work on same task (collaborative)
    
  Check Assignments:
    gitgov task list --assigned-to me                   # Your tasks
    gitgov task list --assigned-to human:developer      # Someone's tasks
```

### **SECTION 4: Complete Command Examples**
```
COMPLETE WORKFLOW EXAMPLE:

1. CREATE A NEW TASK
   $ gitgov task new "Implement user authentication"
   ✅ Task created: 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
   📊 Status: draft

2. SUBMIT DEFINITION FOR REVIEW (draft → review)
   $ gitgov task submit 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
   ✅ Status changed: draft → review
   📝 Task definition sent for approval

3. APPROVE THE DEFINITION (review → ready)
   $ gitgov task approve 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
   ✅ Status changed: review → ready
   🎯 Task approved and ready for implementation

4. ASSIGN TO DEVELOPER (optional, flexible timing)
   $ gitgov task assign 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication --to human:developer
   ✅ Task assigned to human:developer

5. START IMPLEMENTATION (ready → active)
   $ gitgov task activate 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
   ✅ Status changed: ready → active
   🤖 Auto-assigned to current user (if unassigned)
   
   [FUTURE - Automatic activation:]
   $ gitgov exec add 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication --result "Started implementation"
   ✅ Status changed: ready → active (automatic)

6. COMPLETE THE TASK (active → done)
   $ gitgov task complete 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
   ✅ Status changed: active → done
   🎉 Task implementation completed

REJECTION/CANCELLATION EXAMPLES:

7a. REJECT DURING REVIEW (review → discarded)
    $ gitgov task reject 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
    ✅ Status changed: review → discarded
    📝 Task rejected during review phase

7b. CANCEL READY/ACTIVE TASK (ready/active → discarded)
    $ gitgov task cancel 1758573661-task-implement-user-authentication
    ✅ Status changed: ready → discarded
    📝 Task cancelled
```

### **SECTION 5: Common Scenarios**
```
COMMON SCENARIOS:

📝 "I want to create a task"
   → gitgov task new "Your task title"

🔍 "What tasks should I work on?"
   → gitgov task list --status ready
   → gitgov task list --assigned-to me

⚡ "I want to start working on a task"
   → First check: gitgov task show <taskId>
   → If status = ready: gitgov task activate <taskId> (auto-assigns if unassigned)
   → If status = draft: gitgov task submit <taskId>
   → If status = review: gitgov task approve <taskId>

✅ "I finished a task"
   → gitgov task complete <taskId>

❌ "I need to reject/cancel a task"
   → If in review: gitgov task reject <taskId>
   → If ready/active: gitgov task cancel <taskId>

👥 "I want to assign/reassign a task"
   → gitgov task assign <taskId> --to human:developer
   → (Can be done at any status - draft, review, ready, active)

🔄 "I want to see all my tasks"
   → gitgov task list --assigned-to me
   → gitgov status (personal dashboard)

📊 "I want to see project status"
   → gitgov task list --status active
   → gitgov status --all (global dashboard)
```

### **SECTION 6: Auto-Assignment Behavior**
```
AUTO-ASSIGNMENT RULES:

🤖 Smart Assignment:
   - When you activate an unassigned task → auto-assigns to you
   - When you start exec on unassigned task → auto-assigns to you
   - Prevents orphaned tasks and improves accountability

👥 Collaborative Work:
   - Multiple people can be assigned to same task
   - Reassignment is always allowed
   - Assignment can happen at any status (flexible)

📋 Assignment Commands:
   gitgov task assign <taskId> --to human:developer     # Manual assignment
   gitgov task list --assigned-to me                    # Check your assignments
   gitgov task show <taskId> --verbose                  # See assignment history
```

## 🧪 Implementation Requirements

### **COMPONENT 1: Enhanced Help Structure**

Update `packages/cli/src/commands/task/task-command.ts`:
```typescript
// Add comprehensive help text with sections:
// 1. Complete Workflow Overview (including reject/cancel)
// 2. Status Meanings  
// 3. Assignment Workflow (flexible + auto-assignment)
// 4. Complete Command Examples
// 5. Common Scenarios
// 6. Auto-Assignment Behavior
```

### **COMPONENT 2: Interactive Examples**

Include real command examples with:
- Actual task IDs format (timestamp-based)
- Expected outputs for each command
- Status transition explanations
- Assignment workflow examples
- Rejection/cancellation scenarios
- Auto-assignment behavior documentation

### **COMPONENT 3: Workflow Validation**

Ensure help reflects actual workflow from `workflow_methodology_default.json`:
- draft → review (requires: gitgov task submit)
- review → ready (requires: gitgov task approve)
- review → discarded (requires: gitgov task reject)
- ready → active (requires: gitgov task activate, auto-assigns if unassigned)
- ready → discarded (requires: gitgov task cancel)
- active → done (requires: gitgov task complete)
- active → discarded (requires: gitgov task cancel)

### **COMPONENT 4: Auto-Assignment Implementation**

Document the auto-assignment feature for implementation:
```typescript
// In task activate command:
if (task.status === 'ready' && !hasAssignment(taskId)) {
  await autoAssignToCurrentActor(taskId);
}

// Future: In exec add command:
if (task.status === 'ready' && !hasAssignment(taskId)) {
  await autoAssignToCurrentActor(taskId);
}
```

## 📁 Files to Modify

1. **`packages/cli/src/commands/task/task-command.ts`**
   - Enhance main help text with complete workflow sections
   - Add step-by-step examples with reject/cancel
   - Include assignment workflow and auto-assignment behavior
   - Document future exec integration

2. **Consider adding:**
   - `--workflow` flag to show just the workflow diagram
   - `--examples` flag to show just examples
   - `--assignment-help` flag to explain assignment behavior

## 🎯 Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ **Complete Workflow**: Help explains full draft→done flow including reject/cancel paths
2. ✅ **Step-by-Step**: Real examples with actual commands and expected outputs
3. ✅ **Status Meanings**: Clear explanation of each status including discarded
4. ✅ **Assignment Workflow**: Flexible assignment + auto-assignment behavior
5. ✅ **Common Scenarios**: "What should I do?" guidance for all situations
6. ✅ **Rejection/Cancellation**: Clear examples of reject vs cancel usage
7. ✅ **Future Integration**: Document upcoming exec command integration
8. ✅ **AI-Friendly**: Clear enough for @gitgov to understand complete workflow
9. ✅ **Accurate**: Reflects actual workflow_methodology_default.json and task_command.md

## 🚨 Critical Success Factors

- **Educational over Technical**: Focus on "how to use" not "what it does"
- **Complete Command Coverage**: Include ALL subcommands (new, list, show, submit, approve, assign, activate, complete, reject, cancel, edit, promote)
- **Real Examples**: Use actual command formats and expected outputs
- **Progressive Disclosure**: Start simple, add detail
- **AI Consultation Ready**: Perfect for @gitgov to query with `gitgov task -h`
- **Assignment Intelligence**: Document flexible assignment + auto-assignment behavior
- **Rejection Handling**: Clear guidance on when to use reject vs cancel

## 🎯 Special Focus: AI Assistant Integration

This enhancement specifically targets AI assistant consultation:
- **@gitgov can run `gitgov task -h`** to understand complete workflow
- **Clear command examples** for AI to suggest correct commands
- **Status transition logic** for AI to guide users properly
- **Assignment behavior** for AI to understand task ownership
- **Error prevention** by showing complete workflow paths

This will dramatically reduce AI confusion about GitGovernance workflow and make the CLI much more approachable for both humans and AI assistants.

## 🎯 Objective

Implement hybrid release architecture combining CI/CD automation for production releases with @release-agent for pre-release testing and demos.

## 📋 Implementation Steps

### 1. Update Scripts for Pre-release Support
**File: packages/cli/scripts/version.sh**
- Add --prerelease <tag> flag support
- Generate versions like: 1.1.0-demo.1234567890
- Support custom pre-release tags (demo, beta, alpha, etc.)
- Maintain existing production workflow

**File: packages/cli/scripts/release-npm.sh**
- Add --tag <tag> flag support  
- Enable: npm publish --tag demo
- Keep latest tag for production releases

**Expected outcome:**


### 2. Rewrite @release-agent Prompt
**File: docs/release_agent_prompt.md**
- Simplify and focus ONLY on pre-release workflows
- Remove complex branch strategy (CI/CD handles production)
- Clear separation: Agent = pre-releases, CI/CD = production
- Document pre-release testing workflow
- Add examples for demo versions

**Agent responsibilities:**
- Pre-release versions (demo, beta, alpha tags)
- Testing release workflows from feature branches
- Emergency hotfixes validation
- NO production releases (CI/CD handles this)

### 3. Design CI/CD Workflow for Production
**File: .github/workflows/release.yml** (to be created)
- Trigger: push to main branch
- Semantic versioning based on conventional commits
- Automated: build → test → version → npm publish → github release
- Official versions only: 1.0.0, 1.1.0, 1.2.0

**Tools to use:**
- semantic-release for automatic versioning
- GitHub Actions for automation
- NPM_TOKEN for publishing

1. ✅ Scripts support pre-release tags (--prerelease, --tag)

payload.title: Implement proper long description support in task new command
payload.description:
# Implement Proper Long Description Support in task new

## 🐛 PROBLEMA ACTUAL

El comando `gitgov task new` no soporta descripciones largas de manera efectiva:

### Comportamiento Actual:
```bash
gitgov task new "Title" --description "$(cat longfile.md)"
# ❌ Solo guarda: "Description for: Title"
```

### Casos Fallidos:
1. **Heredoc con cat**: No captura el contenido
2. **Piping**: No funciona con stdin
3. **--description flag**: Trunca o ignora contenido largo
4. **Múltiples líneas**: No soportado en flag

## 💡 COMPORTAMIENTO ESPERADO

### Opción 1: Editor Automático (como git commit)
```bash
gitgov task new "Title"
# Abre $EDITOR automáticamente para description
# Usuario escribe, guarda, cierra → description capturada
```

### Opción 2: Flag --description-file
```bash
gitgov task new "Title" --description-file requirements.md
# Lee contenido del archivo
```

### Opción 3: Stdin Support
```bash
cat requirements.md | gitgov task new "Title" --description-stdin
# Lee desde stdin
```

### Opción 4: Editor Explícito
```bash
gitgov task new "Title" --editor
# Fuerza apertura de $EDITOR
```

## 🎯 SOLUCIÓN RECOMENDADA

**Implementar todas las opciones con prioridad:**

1. ✅ **--editor flag** (ya existe pero verificar funcionamiento)
2. 🆕 **--description-file <path>** (nuevo)
3. 🆕 **Mejorar --description** para soportar multiline
4. 🆕 **Auto-editor cuando --description vacío** (opcional)

## 📝 IMPLEMENTACIÓN

   - Agregar flag `--description-stdin`

## ✅ CRITERIOS DE ÉXITO

- [ ] `--description-file` funciona con archivos .md
- [ ] `--description` soporta strings multiline
- [ ] `--editor` abre y captura contenido correctamente

Implement a complete system for discarding tasks with proper semantics and educational error messages.

PROBLEM:
Currently there's no way to discard draft tasks. The system has:
- cancel → ready/active → discarded
- reject → review → discarded
- ??? → draft → ???

SOLUTION:
Add 'delete' command for draft tasks that removes them completely (no discarded state needed since draft never entered formal workflow).

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
1. Implement 'gitgov task delete <id>' command
   - Only works for status=draft
   - Deletes the file directly (no discarded state)
   - Proper error if status != draft

2. Unified educational error messages
   - When wrong command used, suggest correct one
   - Examples:
     * cancel on draft → 'use: gitgov task delete'
     * delete on review → 'use: gitgov task reject'
     * reject on ready → 'use: gitgov task cancel'
   - Consistent format across all discard commands

3. Update protocol documentation
   - Add draft → deleted transition to protocol diagram
   - Document delete command semantics
   - Update task_command.md specs

4. Implementation in BacklogAdapter
   - Add deleteTask() method (only for draft)
   - Validate state before deletion
   - Return helpful error with correct command suggestion

5. CLI command registration
   - Register 'delete' subcommand with alias 'del'
   - Add --force flag for safety
   - JSON output support

SEMANTIC CLARITY:
- delete: Remove draft (never entered workflow)
- reject: Reviewer discards from review
- cancel: Owner discards from ready/active

Build an interactive, immersive knowledge graph visualization that allows navigation across all GitGovernance protocols (tasks, cycles, executions, feedback, changelog, agents) with real-time updates, advanced filtering, and temporal playback capabilities.

**Goal**: Replace static Mermaid diagrams with a scalable, multi-dimensional project visualization tool that enables teams to visualize project evolution over time, identify bottlenecks, track agent activity in real-time, and navigate complex relationships between entities at scale (1000+ nodes).

---

## ✅ Acceptance Criteria

### Must Have (MVP - Phase 1)

- [ ] **Data Loading**: Load and parse tasks + cycles from 
- [ ] **Basic Graph Rendering**: Display nodes (tasks, cycles) and edges (relationships) using force-directed layout
- [ ] **Visual Encoding**:
  - Tasks as rectangles with size proportional to complexity
  - Cycles as rounded containers
  - Color coding by status (draft=gray, ready=yellow, active=blue, done=green, blocked=red, archived=light-gray)
- [ ] **Interactivity**:
  - Click on node → Show detailed sidebar with full entity data
  - Hover on node → Highlight direct relationships
  - Zoom and pan navigation
  - Drag nodes to reorganize
- [ ] **Basic Filters**:
  - Filter by status (draft, ready, active, done, blocked, archived)
  - Filter by priority (low, medium, high, critical)
  - Filter by entity type (task, cycle)
- [ ] **Performance**: Render up to 500 nodes without lag (<100ms render time)

### Should Have (Phase 2 - Multiprotocolo)

- [ ] **Extended Data Loading**: Load executions, feedback, changelog from 
- [ ] **Multi-Entity Visualization**:
  - Executions as activity pulses on tasks
  - Feedback as halos around entities (color by status: open=orange, resolved=green)
  - Changelog as temporal trails showing history
  - Agents as animated avatars moving between tasks
- [ ] **Relationship Types**:
  - Dependencies (solid lines)
  - Blockers (red pulsing lines)
  - Cycle containment (orbital grouping)
  - Feedback threads (conversation lines)
  - Execution history (activity trails)
- [ ] **Advanced Filters**:
  - Filter by date range
  - Filter by actor (assignee, creator)
  - Filter by tags
  - Filter by relationship type
  - Combined filters with AND/OR logic
- [ ] **Timeline View**: Alternative layout showing entities on temporal axis

### Could Have (Phase 3 - Real-time & Analytics)

- [ ] **Real-time Updates**: WebSocket/SSE integration for live updates when entities change
- [ ] **Visual Analytics**:
  - Heatmap overlay showing activity density
  - Critical path highlighting (longest dependency chain)
  - Bottleneck detection (nodes with most blockers)
  - Agent workload visualization (tasks per agent)
  - Stale entity detection (no activity in N days)
- [ ] **Search & Navigation**:
  - Full-text search across all entities
  - Auto-zoom to search results
  - Breadcrumb navigation for complex paths
- [ ] **Export**: Export current view as SVG/PNG

### Nice to Have (Phase 4 - Immersive Experience)

- [ ] **Time Travel**: Playback slider to see project evolution over time
- [ ] **3D View**: Optional 3D force-directed graph using Three.js
- [ ] **Predictive Analytics**: ML-based prediction of tasks at risk
- [ ] **Collaborative Features**: Multi-cursor support for team exploration
- [ ] **Custom Layouts**: User-defined layouts (hierarchical, circular, radial)

---

### Technology Stack

payload.title: Reorganize protocol folder numbering to reflect logical dependencies
payload.description:
# Reorganize protocol folder numbering to reflect logical dependencies

## Problem

The current folder order in `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/` does not reflect the conceptual and logical dependencies between protocols:

**Current Order:**
```
01_embedded
02_actor
03_agent
04_task
06_execution
07_changelog
08_feedback
05_cycle
09_workflow_methodology
10_planning_methodology
12_persistence
13_metrics
99_appendices
```

**Issues:**
- `05_cycle` should come before `06_execution` because it defines the temporal/strategic context
- `cycle` groups `tasks`, so conceptually it should come before execution records
- Current order makes onboarding difficult for new developers
- Does not reflect the logical implementation sequence

## Proposed Solution

Reorder folders following conceptual dependencies:

**New Order:**
```
01_embedded          (technical foundation - metadata structure)
02_actor             (identities - who signs/works)
03_agent             (specific AI agents)
04_task              (what to do - atomic unit of work)
05_cycle             (when/how to group - sprint/milestone)
06_execution         (progress tracking on tasks)
07_changelog         (compiled history)
08_feedback          (continuous improvement)
09_workflow_methodology
10_planning_methodology
11_persistence       (currently 12)
12_metrics           (currently 13)
99_appendices
```

## Rationale

1. **Task before Cycle**: Tasks can exist without cycles (`cycleIds` is optional), but Cycles group Tasks
2. **Cycle before Execution**: First define WHAT and WHEN (task + cycle), then record work (execution)
3. **Persistence before Metrics**: Metrics depend on how data is persisted

## Specific Tasks

1. Rename folders while keeping content intact:
   - `05_cycle` → `05_cycle`
   - `06_execution` → `06_execution`
   - `07_changelog` → `07_changelog`
   - `08_feedback` → `08_feedback`
   - `12_persistence` → `11_persistence`
   - `13_metrics` → `12_metrics`

2. Update cross-references in documentation:
   - Search for old path references
   - Update imports/links in other protocols
   - Verify examples still work

3. Update scripts/tooling that depend on these paths (if any)

## Impact

- **Low risk**: Only folder name changes, no content changes
- **High benefit**: Better system understanding for new contributors
- **Documentation**: More intuitive and easier to follow sequentially

## References

- Discussion about logical order vs functional implementation
- System currently functional without cycle/execution/feedback fully implemented
- Need to improve developer experience and onboarding

# Implementar CLI Commands del Feedback Protocol

## Contexto

El `FeedbackAdapter` core está completo (6/6 métodos, patrón inmutable). El blueprint `feedback_command.md` está completamente documentado con 5 comandos y 20 EARS, pero **ningún comando CLI está implementado** aún.

## Problema

Los comandos `gitgov feedback` no existen. El sistema depende de que los usuarios usen el adapter programáticamente o vía `gitgov task assign` (que usa el adapter internamente).

**Impacto:**
- No hay forma de crear feedback blocking desde CLI
- No hay forma de crear feedback question desde CLI
- No hay forma de ver threads de conversación
- Workflow de comunicación estructurada está incompleto

## Solución

Implementar los 5 comandos CLI documentados en `feedback_command.md`:

### 1. `gitgov feedback create`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/create.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Validar entity existe
- Crear FeedbackRecord vía FeedbackAdapter
- Emitir evento para side effects
- Output formateado (no-json mode)

**EARS CLI:** EARS-1 a EARS-6 (validation, entity checking, defaults)

### 2. `gitgov feedback list`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/list.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Auto-indexation
- Filtrado por status, entity, assignee, type
- Default: excluir resolved
- Output table/JSON

**EARS CLI:** EARS-10 a EARS-15 (filtros, defaults)

### 3. `gitgov feedback show`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/show.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Mostrar feedback completo
- Opción --context (entity context)
- Opción --thread (conversation tree)
- Opción --signatures

**EARS CLI:** EARS-16 a EARS-18 (show, context, thread)

### 4. `gitgov feedback reply`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/reply.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Helper UX para responder
- Delega a create() internamente
- Defaults: type=clarification, status=resolved

**EARS CLI:** EARS-7 a EARS-9 (reply helper, defaults)

### 5. `gitgov feedback thread`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/thread.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Construir árbol de conversación
- Opción --depth
- Renderizar thread visualmente
- Output JSON

**EARS CLI:** EARS-19, EARS-20 (thread building, depth limit)

## Dependencias

**Adapters requeridos:**
- ✅ FeedbackAdapter (implementado)
- ✅ BacklogAdapter (para validar entities)
- ✅ IdentityAdapter (para getCurrentActor)
- ✅ IndexerAdapter (para auto-indexation)

**Patrones a seguir:**
- Similar a `task_command.ts` (ya implementado)
- Similar a `cycle_command.ts` (ya implementado)
- Auto-indexation en comandos de lectura
- Invalidate cache en comandos de escritura

## Referencias

**Blueprint completo:**
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/cli/specs/feedback_command.md` (821 líneas)
- Flags detallados, ejemplos, EARS, planning brief

**Adapters:**
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/adapters/feedback_adapter.md`

## Criterios de Aceptación

1. ✅ 5 comandos implementados y funcionando
2. ✅ 20 EARS CLI cubiertos con E2E tests
3. ✅ Auto-indexation funcionando en list/show/thread
4. ✅ Side effects automáticos (blocking → pause task)
5. ✅ Output formateado (table + JSON modes)
6. ✅ Help text completo para cada comando
7. ✅ Integración con adapter core sin errores

## Estimación

**Complejidad:** Alta (5 comandos + 20 EARS + side effects)
**Tiempo estimado:** 1-2 semanas
**Prioridad:** Medium (adapter funciona programáticamente)
**Bloqueado por:** Task 1761603296 (EARS-36) debe completarse primero

payload.description:
# Translate Protocol Documentation: Design i18n structure and implement English version

## Context

All GitGovernance protocols are currently documented in **Spanish**. To make the project accessible to the global developer community, we need to:
1. Design the internationalization (i18n) structure
2. Translate all protocols to English
3. Maintain both versions going forward

This is critical for open-source adoption and international collaboration.

## Problem

**Current state:**
- ✅ 9 protocols fully documented in Spanish
- ❌ No English version available
- ❌ No i18n structure defined
- ❌ No process for maintaining translations

**Impact:**
- Non-Spanish developers cannot understand the protocol
- Open-source contributions limited
- International adoption blocked

## Solution - i18n Structure Design

### Option A: Language Subdirectories (RECOMMENDED)

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/
├── es/  ← Spanish (original)
│   ├── 01_embedded/
│   │   ├── embedded_metadata_protocol.md
│   │   └── embedded_metadata_schema.yaml
│   ├── 04_task/
│   │   ├── task_protocol.md
│   │   ├── task_protocol_faq.md
│   │   └── task_record_schema.yaml
│   └── ...
├── en/  ← English (translated)
│   ├── 01_embedded/
│   │   ├── embedded_metadata_protocol.md
│   │   └── embedded_metadata_schema.yaml  ← Same (no translation needed)
│   ├── 04_task/
│   │   ├── task_protocol.md
│   │   ├── task_protocol_faq.md
│   │   └── task_record_schema.yaml  ← Same
│   └── ...
└── README.md  ← Bilingual navigation
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ Clean separation
- ✅ Easy to add more languages (pt/, fr/, etc.)
- ✅ Default language configurable
- ✅ Schemas shared (no duplication)

**Disadvantages:**
- ⚠️ Duplication of schemas (or symlinks needed)
- ⚠️ Cross-references need language-aware paths

### Option B: Suffix-Based Files

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/
├── 04_task/
│   ├── task_protocol.es.md  ← Spanish
│   ├── task_protocol.en.md  ← English
│   ├── task_protocol_faq.es.md
│   ├── task_protocol_faq.en.md
│   └── task_record_schema.yaml  ← Shared (no translation)
└── ...
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ Schemas stay in same directory
- ✅ Easy to see translation status (missing .en.md files)

**Disadvantages:**
- ⚠️ Directory clutter (2x files)
- ⚠️ Harder to maintain consistency

### Option C: Separate Repo/Package for Translations

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/  ← Spanish (source of truth)
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol-en/  ← English (separate)
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ No impact on original structure
- ✅ Can have different maintainers

**Disadvantages:**
- ❌ Hard to keep in sync
- ❌ Schemas duplicated

### Recommended: Option A (Language Subdirectories)

**Implementation:**

1. Create `/es/` and `/en/` directories
2. Move current Spanish docs to `/es/`
3. Keep schemas in both (or symlink to `/es/`)
4. Translate to `/en/`
5. Update `pnpm sync:schemas` to handle both languages

## Scope of Work

### Phase 1: Structure Design (1-2 hours)

**Decisions needed:**
- Choose Option A, B, or C
- Define schema handling (duplicate vs symlink)
- Define cross-reference format for i18n
- Update build scripts (`sync:schemas`, `compile:types`)

### Phase 2: Move Current Spanish Docs (2-3 hours)

**Tasks:**
- Create `/es/` directory structure
- Move all `*_protocol.md` files to `/es/`
- Move all `*_protocol_faq.md` files to `/es/`
- Decide schema location (keep in `/es/` or root)
- Update all internal cross-references
- Verify `pnpm sync:schemas` still works

### Phase 3: Translate to English (2-3 weeks)

**9 Protocols to translate:**

| Protocol | Files to Translate | Estimated Lines | Time |
|:---|:---|---:|:---:|
| EmbeddedMetadata | protocol.md | ~200 | 2h |
| Actor | protocol.md + FAQ | ~300 | 3h |
| Agent | protocol.md | ~200 | 2h |
| Task | protocol.md + FAQ | ~450 | 4h |
| Cycle | protocol.md + FAQ | ~350 | 3h |
| Execution | protocol.md + appendix + FAQ | ~600 | 6h |
| Changelog | protocol.md + FAQ | ~400 | 4h |
| Feedback | protocol.md + FAQ | ~500 | 5h |
| WorkflowMethodology | protocol.md | ~400 | 4h |
| PlanningMethodology | protocol.md (if exists) | ~300 | 3h |

**Total:** ~3,700 lines, ~36 hours of translation work

**Translation quality requirements:**
- Technical accuracy (preserve meaning)
- Consistent terminology
- Professional tone
- Code examples stay in English
- YAML schemas unchanged

### Phase 4: Bilingual README (1-2 hours)

**Create:** `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/README.md`

**Content:**
```markdown
# GitGovernance Protocols / Protocolos GitGovernance

[English](#english) | [Español](#español)

## English

GitGovernance defines 9 core protocols...

**Available Protocols:**
- [Embedded Metadata](en/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_protocol.md)
- [Task Protocol](en/04_task/task_protocol.md)
- ...

## Español

GitGovernance define 9 protocolos core...

**Protocolos Disponibles:**
- [Metadatos Embebidos](es/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_protocol.md)
- [Protocolo de Tareas](es/04_task/task_protocol.md)
- ...
```

### Phase 5: Update Build Scripts (2-3 hours)

**Update:** `packages/core/scripts/sync-schemas.ts`

**Changes needed:**
```typescript
// Support both /es/ and /en/ paths
const PROTOCOL_DIRS = [
  '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/es/',
  '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/en/'  // If schemas duplicated
];

// Or: Only sync from /es/ (source of truth)
const PROTOCOL_DIR = '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/es/';
```

## Deliverables

1. ✅ i18n structure decision document
2. ✅ `/es/` directory with all Spanish docs
3. ✅ `/en/` directory with all English translations
4. ✅ Bilingual main README
5. ✅ Updated build scripts supporting i18n
6. ✅ Translation consistency guide
7. ✅ Verification: schemas generate from both languages

## Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ i18n structure implemented (Option A, B, or C)
2. ✅ All Spanish docs moved to `/es/` (or renamed with .es.md)
3. ✅ All 9 protocols translated to English
4. ✅ Technical terminology consistent across translations
5. ✅ Code examples preserved correctly
6. ✅ Bilingual README with clear navigation
7. ✅ Build scripts work with new structure
8. ✅ `pnpm sync:schemas` generates schemas correctly
9. ✅ Cross-references work in both languages

## Translation Strategy

### Terminology Dictionary (to maintain consistency)

| Spanish | English | Notes |
|:---|:---|:---|
| Tarea | Task | Core entity |
| Ciclo | Cycle | Strategic planning |
| Ejecución | Execution | Work chronicle |
| Retroalimentación | Feedback | Structured communication |
| Registro de Cambios | Changelog | Release notes |
| Metadatos Embebidos | Embedded Metadata | Infrastructure |
| Metodología de Flujo | Workflow Methodology | State transitions |
| Metodología de Planificación | Planning Methodology | Epic decomposition |
| Firma | Signature | Cryptographic |
| Auditoría | Audit | Quality gates |

### Translation Tools

**Options:**
1. **Manual** - High quality, time-consuming
2. **AI-assisted** - Fast, needs review
3. **Hybrid** - AI first draft + human review (RECOMMENDED)

**Quality check:**
- Technical reviewer (bilingual developer)
- Consistency validator (terminology)
- Cross-reference tester

## Dependencies

**Bloqueado por:**
- Task 1761604438 (ExecutionAdapter verification)
- Task 1761604451 (ChangelogAdapter verification)
- Task 1761604701 (WorkflowMethodology verification)
- Task 1761604714 (PlanningMethodology verification)
- Previous task (v1.0.0 coherence review)

**Reason:** Protocols must be 100% coherent in Spanish before translating to avoid translating inconsistencies.

## Estimation

**Complexity:** Medium (translation work, structure design)
**Time:** 
- Structure design + migration: 1 day
- Translation (9 protocols): 2-3 weeks
- Review + fixes: 3-5 days
- **Total:** 3-4 weeks
**Priority:** Medium (important for adoption, not blocking current work)
**Risk:** Low (mostly documentation work)
**Tags:** `protocol`, `i18n`, `translation`, `documentation`, `english`, `español`

payload.title: Fix Missing notes Field in Signature Objects Across Tests
payload.description:
# Fix Missing `notes` Field in Signature Objects Across Tests

## Problem

Multiple test files (31 tests failing) are creating signature objects that don't comply with `embedded_metadata_schema.yaml`. The schema requires the `notes` field in all signature objects, but many tests omit it.

### Schema Requirement (embedded_metadata_schema.yaml:55-59)

```yaml
notes:
  type: string
  minLength: 1
  maxLength: 1000
  description: "Human-readable note from the signer. Part of the signature digest."
```

**Required fields:** keyId, role, **notes**, signature, timestamp, timestamp_iso

### Current Violations

**Example from CLI tests:**
```typescript
// ❌ INVALID (missing notes)
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test-user',
  role: 'creator',
  timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
  signature: 'test-signature'
}]
```

**Example from Core validators:**
```typescript
// ❌ INVALID (missing notes)
signatures: [{ 
  keyId: 'human:test', 
  role: 'author', 
  signature: 'sig', 
  timestamp: 123, 
  timestamp_iso: '' 
}]
```

### Affected Files (28 total)

**Core package (25 files):**
- `packages/core/src/validation/*.test.ts` (9 files)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/*/index.ts` (5 files)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/*/*.test.ts` (10 files)
- `packages/core/src/crypto/signatures.test.ts`
- `packages/core/src/store/record_store.test.ts`

**CLI package (3 files):**
- `packages/cli/e2e/task_command_e2e.test.ts`
- `packages/cli/e2e/dashboard_command_e2e.test.ts`
- `packages/cli/e2e/diagram_command_e2e.test.ts`

## Solution

### Step 1: Audit All Signature Objects

Search for all occurrences of `signatures: [` in:
- `packages/core/src/**/*.ts`
- `packages/cli/**/*.ts`

### Step 2: Add Missing `notes` Field

For each signature object, add the required `notes` field:

```typescript
// ✅ VALID
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test-user',
  role: 'creator',
  notes: 'Test signature for unit testing',  // 👈 ADD THIS
  timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
  signature: 'test-signature'
}]
```

**Guidelines for `notes` content:**
- **Production code:** Use descriptive notes explaining the signature context
- **Test code:** Use `''` (empty string) or simple descriptions like `'Test signature'`
- **Examples (from schema):** Follow patterns in embedded_metadata_schema.yaml lines 190, 209, 215, 234, 240

### Step 3: Special Cases

**Case A: Type-casting signatures (tests)**
```typescript
// ✅ Ensure all fields present before casting
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test',
  role: 'author',
  notes: '',  // Required even for test mocks
  signature: 'sig',
  timestamp: 123,
  timestamp_iso: '2025-01-01T00:00:00Z'
}] as [Signature, ...Signature[]]
```

**Case B: Dynamic signature creation**
```typescript
// ✅ Ensure factory functions include notes
const signature = {
  keyId: actorId,
  role: 'author',
  notes: '',  // Default for generated signatures
  signature: 'placeholder',
  timestamp: Date.now(),
  timestamp_iso: new Date().toISOString()
}
```

### Step 4: Verify TypeScript Compliance

After changes, verify:
```bash
cd packages/core && npx tsc --noEmit
cd packages/cli && npx tsc --noEmit
```

### Step 5: Run Tests

```bash
cd packages/core && pnpm test
cd packages/cli && pnpm test:e2e
```

## Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ All signature objects include the `notes` field
2. ✅ TypeScript compiles without errors
3. ✅ All tests pass (currently 728 passing → 759 passing)
4. ✅ No implicit `any` types remain
5. ✅ Schema compliance verified in all production code

## References

- **Schema:** `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_schema.yaml`
- **Examples:** Lines 188-249 in schema (shows proper `notes` usage)
- **Related Issue:** This blocks proper signature verification in production

## Estimated Effort

- **Complexity:** Low (mechanical changes)
- **Time:** 1-2 hours (28 files to update)
- **Risk:** Low (purely additive change)

payload.description:
# Wrap WorkflowMethodologyRecord in EmbeddedMetadata

## Context
Currently `WorkflowMethodologyRecord` is stored as plain YAML config without audit trail, signatures, or versioning. This creates an architectural inconsistency with all other Records and lacks governance controls.

## Problem
- No signature verification for methodology changes
- No audit trail of who modified what and when
- No checksum integrity validation
- Inconsistent architecture (only Record type not wrapped in EmbeddedMetadata)

## Proposed Solution
Wrap `WorkflowMethodologyRecord` in `EmbeddedMetadata` (like all other 7 Records) to enable:
1. **Signature verification** for methodology changes
2. **Audit trail** of modifications (who, when, what)
3. **Checksum integrity** validation
4. **Consistent architecture** across all Records

## Technical Scope

### Files to Modify/Create (~12-15 files)
1. **Validator** (~30 lines)
   - Add `validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord` with EARS 1-4
   - Update tests with EARS 1-4 coverage

2. **Factory** (new file ~80 lines)
   - Create `createWorkflowMethodologyRecord`
   - Uses `createEmbeddedMetadataRecord` internally
   - Full test coverage

3. **ConfigManager** (~50 lines)
   - Backward compatibility for existing YAML files
   - Detect format (old vs new)
   - Handle both transparently

4. **CLI** (~40 lines)
   - Auto-wrap on save
   - Auto-unwrap on load
   - Maintain UX consistency

5. **Integration Tests** (new file ~100 lines)
   - Test migration path
   - Test backward compatibility
   - Test new workflow

## Challenges

### 🔴 CRITICAL: Backward Compatibility
- Existing `.gitgov/workflow_methodology.yaml` files must continue working without changes
- ConfigManager must detect format and handle both
- Migration must be transparent to users

### Strategy
```typescript
// ConfigManager: Detect format
function loadWorkflowMethodology(): WorkflowMethodologyRecord {
  const raw = readYAML('.gitgov/workflow_methodology.yaml');
  
  // New format: has header + payload
  if (raw.header && raw.payload) {
    await validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord(raw, getPublicKey);
    return raw.payload;
  }
  
  // Old format: plain config
  validateWorkflowMethodologyConfigDetailed(raw);
  return raw;
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord` implements EARS 1-4
- [ ] Factory creates properly signed `WorkflowMethodologyRecord`
- [ ] ConfigManager loads both old and new formats transparently
- [ ] CLI wraps on save, unwraps on load
- [ ] All existing projects continue working without changes
- [ ] Integration tests cover migration path (old → new)
- [ ] Documentation updated (blueprint + CLI docs)
- [ ] All 133+ existing tests continue passing

## Estimated Effort
**2-3 days** of focused work (~17-20 hours)

## References
- `validator_module.md` - Generic EARS 1-16 specification
- `execution_validator.ts` - Reference implementation for Records with EmbeddedMetadata
- `task_validator.ts` - Another reference implementation
- `workflow_methodology_validator.ts` - Current implementation (no EmbeddedMetadata)

## Tags
architecture, consistency, governance, audit-trail, signatures

## Priority
Medium (Important for architecture consistency, but existing system works)

payload.description:
# Fix Performance Bug in FeedbackAdapter - EARS-29 Test Failure

## 🐛 Problema

El test de performance `[EARS-29] should filter 1000+ feedbacks in under 100ms` está fallando en `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts`:

```
Expected: < 100
Received:   128
```

**Tipo de Requisito:** Requisito No Funcional (NFR) de Performance  
**EARS Afectado:** EARS-29 (definido en blueprint)  
**Estado Actual:** ❌ Test falla por exceso de tiempo (28% más lento que el target)

## 📊 Evidencia del Fallo

```bash
pnpm test
# Output:
 FAIL  src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts
  ● FeedbackAdapter › Performance - Advanced › [EARS-29] should filter 1000+ feedbacks in under 100ms

    expect(received).toBeLessThan(expected)

    Expected: < 100
    Received:   128

      at Object.<anonymous> (src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts:931:35)
```

## 🔍 Análisis de Causa Raíz

### Implementación Actual (Secuencial - INEFICIENTE)

El método `getFeedbackByEntity()` en `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts` (líneas 244-256) ejecuta las lecturas **secuencialmente**:

```typescript
async getFeedbackByEntity(entityId: string): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  const feedbacks: FeedbackRecord[] = [];

  // ❌ PROBLEMA: Loop secuencial - espera cada await antes de continuar
  for (const id of ids) {
    const record = await this.feedbackStore.read(id);
    if (record && record.payload.entityId === entityId) {
      feedbacks.push(record.payload);
    }
  }

  return feedbacks;
}
```

**Por qué es lento:**
- Con 1200 feedbacks en el test, ejecuta 1200 llamadas `await` secuenciales
- Cada llamada espera a que la anterior termine antes de iniciar
- Tiempo total = suma de todos los tiempos de lectura individuales
- Resultado: 128ms (excede el límite de 100ms)

### Problema Secundario: `getAllFeedback()` Tiene el Mismo Patrón

El método `getAllFeedback()` (líneas 266-278) usa el mismo patrón secuencial ineficiente:

```typescript
async getAllFeedback(): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  const feedbacks: FeedbackRecord[] = [];

  // ❌ Mismo problema de performance
  for (const id of ids) {
    const record = await this.feedbackStore.read(id);
    if (record) {
      feedbacks.push(record.payload);
    }
  }

  return feedbacks;
}
```

## ✅ Solución Propuesta: Paralelización con Promise.all()

### Para `getFeedbackByEntity()`:

```typescript
async getFeedbackByEntity(entityId: string): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  
  // ✅ SOLUCIÓN: Ejecutar todas las lecturas en paralelo
  const records = await Promise.all(
    ids.map(id => this.feedbackStore.read(id))
  );
  
  // Filtrar y extraer payloads
  return records
    .filter(record => record && record.payload.entityId === entityId)
    .map(record => record!.payload);
}
```

### Para `getAllFeedback()`:

```typescript
async getAllFeedback(): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  
  // ✅ Paralelización
  const records = await Promise.all(
    ids.map(id => this.feedbackStore.read(id))
  );
  
  // Filtrar nulos y extraer payloads
  return records
    .filter(record => record !== null)
    .map(record => record!.payload);
}
```

## 📈 Mejora de Performance Esperada

- **Antes (secuencial):** ~128ms para 1200 feedbacks
- **Después (paralelo):** ~10-50ms para 1200 feedbacks (dependiendo del mock)
- **Reducción esperada:** 60-87% menos tiempo
- **Test EARS-29:** ✅ Debería pasar (<100ms)

## 🎯 Cambios a Realizar

### Archivo: `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts`

1. **Modificar `getFeedbackByEntity()` (líneas 244-256)**
   - Reemplazar el loop `for...of` secuencial
   - Implementar `Promise.all()` con `.map()`
   - Usar encadenamiento funcional con `.filter()` y `.map()`

2. **Modificar `getAllFeedback()` (líneas 266-278)**
   - Aplicar el mismo patrón de paralelización
   - Mantener la lógica de filtrado de nulos

### Archivo de Tests: `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts`

**NO requiere cambios** - El test está correctamente implementado y pasará automáticamente al optimizar el código.

## 📋 Criterios de Aceptación

1. ✅ Test `[EARS-29] should filter 1000+ feedbacks in under 100ms` debe pasar
2. ✅ Todos los tests existentes de `FeedbackAdapter` deben seguir pasando (45 tests, 1024 passed)
3. ✅ Performance mejorada sin cambiar la API pública (sin breaking changes)
4. ✅ Mantener el comportamiento funcional idéntico (solo optimización interna)
5. ✅ Código más legible usando paradigma funcional (map/filter)

## 🔗 Referencias

### Archivos Afectados:
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts` (implementación)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts` (test que valida el fix)

### Documentación:
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/adapters/feedback_adapter.md`:
  - **Línea 434:** Definición de EARS-29 (requisito de performance)
  - **Línea 481:** Estado de implementación del test (actualmente ❌)

### EARS Relacionados:
- **EARS-29:** Debe filtrar 1000+ feedbacks en <100ms
- **EARS-28:** Debe ejecutarse en <50ms para datasets típicos
- **EARS-30:** Debe construir thread de 20+ niveles en <200ms (no afectado por este cambio)

## 🏷️ Metadata

- **Tipo:** Bug Fix (Performance)
- **Prioridad:** High (afecta test suite)
- **Complejidad:** Baja (cambio algorítmico simple, 2 métodos)
- **Impacto:** Performance crítica para sistemas con muchos feedbacks
- **Tiempo Estimado:** 15-30 minutos
- **Testing:** Automático (test existente valida el fix)

## 🚀 Estrategia de Implementación

1. **Modificar `getFeedbackByEntity()`:**
   - Reemplazar loop secuencial por `Promise.all()`
   - Usar encadenamiento funcional

2. **Modificar `getAllFeedback()`:**
   - Aplicar mismo patrón de paralelización

3. **Verificar Tests:**
   ```bash
   cd packages/core
   pnpm test feedback_adapter.test.ts
   ```

4. **Validar Suite Completa:**
   ```bash
   pnpm test
   ```

5. **Verificar Blueprint:**
   - Actualizar estado de EARS-29 en tabla de trazabilidad (línea 481)
   - Cambiar ❌ por ✅ en el estado de implementación

## 💡 Notas Adicionales

- Este patrón de paralelización es común en Node.js para I/O operations
- No hay riesgo de race conditions ya que las lecturas son operaciones independientes
- El método `buildThread()` (líneas 295-336) también usa loops secuenciales pero es correcto porque necesita construir el árbol recursivamente respetando el orden
- La optimización solo aplica cuando las operaciones son completamente independientes entre sí

# Agregar dependencia faltante `dotenv` a @gitgov/core

## 📋 Contexto

Durante una auditoría exhaustiva de dependencias en `packages/core` usando el protocolo `@dependency-auditor-agent`, se detectó una **dependencia faltante crítica**.

## 🔍 Problema Detectado

El archivo `packages/core/jest.env.js` utiliza `dotenv` pero no está declarado en `package.json`:

```javascript
// packages/core/jest.env.js:1
const { config } = require('dotenv');
```

**Evidencia de búsqueda:**
```bash
grep -r "require\(['\"']dotenv['\"']\)" packages/core/
# Result: packages/core/jest.env.js:1
```

**Estado actual:** La dependencia NO existe en `dependencies` ni en `devDependencies`.

## ✅ Solución Propuesta

Agregar `dotenv` como `devDependency` ya que solo se usa en el entorno de testing:

```bash
cd packages/core
pnpm add -D dotenv
```

## 🎯 Clasificación

- **Tipo de uso:** Configuración de entorno de testing (jest.env.js)
- **Clasificación correcta:** `devDependencies` (no se necesita en runtime de producción)
- **Prioridad:** Media (el proyecto funciona actualmente, posiblemente por hoisting de pnpm workspace)

## 🧪 Validación Post-Cambio

Después de agregar la dependencia, verificar:

```bash
cd packages/core

# 1. Reinstalar dependencias
pnpm install

# 2. Verificar compilación TypeScript
npx tsc --noEmit

# 3. Ejecutar tests
pnpm test
```

## 📊 Resultado de Auditoría Completa

**Dependencias auditadas:** 17 total (3 production, 14 development)
- ✅ Correctamente clasificadas: 16
- ❌ Faltantes: 1 (`dotenv`)
- ✅ Sin uso: 0
- ✅ Mal clasificadas: 0

**Conclusión:** El proyecto tiene una gestión de dependencias excelente, solo falta agregar esta única dependencia.

## 🔗 Referencias

- Package.json: `packages/core/package.json`
- Protocolo usado: `docs/dependency_auditor_agent_prompt.md`

payload.description:
# Persist Actor Private Keys to Disk

## Problem

Currently, when creating an ActorRecord via `gitgov init`, the private key is generated but:
- ❌ Only displayed once in the terminal (can be lost)
- ❌ Not persisted to disk
- ✅ `.gitignore` already configured for `.gitgov/actors/*.key`

This means users cannot sign records after initialization unless they saved the key manually.

## Solution

Modify `IdentityAdapter.createActor()` to persist private keys:

1. Save private key to `.gitgov/actors/{actorId}.key` (base64 format)
2. Set file permissions to `0600` (owner read/write only)
3. Load private key when needed for signing operations
4. Update documentation about key management

## Implementation Notes

- File: `packages/core/src/adapters/identity_adapter/index.ts`
- Already gitignored: `.gitgov/actors/*.key`
- Format: Base64-encoded PKCS8 PEM (current privateKey format)
- Security: File permissions `0600` (Node.js `fs.chmod`)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Private key saved to `.gitgov/actors/{actorId}.key` on actor creation
- [ ] File has secure permissions (0600)
- [ ] Key can be loaded for signing operations
- [ ] Tests verify key persistence and loading
- [ ] Documentation updated with key management guidelines

Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for main
payload.description:
# Task: Establish CI Pipeline and Required Checks for `main`

## Summary
Create a lightweight but reliable Continuous Integration (CI) workflow that runs on every Pull Request targeting `main`. The workflow must validate code quality and prevent risky merges by enforcing **required checks** in a GitHub Ruleset.

This document is intended to be used as a long description when creating a governance task (e.g., with `--description-file /tmp/ci-task.md`).

---

## Objectives
1. **Prevent broken code** from being merged into `main`.
2. **Provide fast feedback** to contributors (target: < 10 minutes for PR CI).
3. **Align with Ruleset protections** by supplying named checks that can be marked as _required_.
4. **Do not publish artifacts or releases** from PRs. Releases remain on `push` to `main` via existing release workflows.

---

## Scope
- Add a new workflow: `.github/workflows/ci.yml`.
- Run on `pull_request` to `main` (and optionally on `push` to `main` for visibility).
- Include the following validation steps:
  - **Lint**
  - **Type check**
  - **Build**
  - **Unit tests**
  - (Optional) **Dependency audit**, **Prettier check**, **Size limit**

- Expose each validation as a **separate job** so they appear as distinct checks in the Ruleset.
- Keep the CI **idempotent and safe** (no publishing, no environment mutations).

Out of scope: release automation, deployment, environment provisioning.

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- A new workflow file exists at `.github/workflows/ci.yml`.
- Opening a PR against `main` triggers the workflow.
- The workflow publishes the following check names (jobs):
  - `lint`
  - `typecheck`
  - `build`
  - `test`
  - (optional) `audit`
- The repository’s Ruleset for `main` has **Require status checks to pass** enabled and includes the above jobs as **required checks**.
- **Require branches to be up to date before merging** is enabled in the Ruleset.
- The workflow completes in **≤ 10 minutes** under typical loads.
- The workflow does **not** publish or release anything on PRs.

---

## Design & Implementation Details

### Triggers
- `pull_request` → `branches: [ main ]`
- Optional: `push` to `main` for post-merge visibility.

### Permissions
Use least privilege for Actions:
```yaml
permissions:
  contents: read
```

### Caching
- Use built-in `actions/setup-*` caching where possible.
- Prefer `npm ci` / `pnpm install --frozen-lockfile` to ensure deterministic installs.

### Monorepo Considerations
- If the project uses `packages/core` and `packages/cli`, run commands with `--workspaces` or set `working-directory` per job.
- Optionally scope workflow with `paths` to avoid running on docs-only changes.

### Naming
The **job id** becomes the **status check name** in the Ruleset. Use concise, stable ids:
- `lint`, `typecheck`, `build`, `test`, `audit`

### Example Workflow (Node.js / TypeScript, workspaces-friendly)
```yaml
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: CI

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main ]
    # Optionally restrict files that trigger CI:
    # paths: [ "packages/**", ".github/workflows/ci.yml" ]
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

concurrency:
  group: ci-${{ github.ref }}
  cancel-in-progress: true

permissions:
  contents: read

jobs:
  lint:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run lint --workspaces --if-present
      - run: npx prettier --check .

  typecheck:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npx tsc --noEmit || npx tsc -b --noEmit

  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: [lint, typecheck]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build --workspaces --if-present
      - uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: dist
          path: |
            packages/**/dist
            !**/node_modules/**

  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm test --workspaces --if-present -- --ci --reporters=default
      # - run: npm test -- --coverage  # enable if you want coverage reports

  audit:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci --omit=dev
      - run: npm audit --audit-level=high
```

> Adapt commands to your package manager (`npm`, `pnpm`, `yarn`) and project structure. If some scripts are missing, remove those steps or add scripts in `package.json` (e.g., `lint`, `build`, `test`).

### Paths Optimization (optional)
If the repo has docs or non-code folders, restrict triggers to relevant paths:
```yaml
on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main ]
    paths: [ "packages/**", ".github/workflows/ci.yml" ]
```

### Secrets
This CI design **does not require secrets**. If tests need secrets, use repository or environment secrets and **do not** mark that job as required until secrets are stable.

### Artifacts
Artifacts (e.g., `dist/`) are uploaded for debugging; they are not released. Retention can be lowered to save storage.

---

## Ruleset Integration (Branch Protection)

In the Ruleset that targets `main`, ensure:
- **Require a pull request before merging** → enabled (with at least 1 approval).
- **Require status checks to pass** → enabled.
- **Require branches to be up to date before merging** → enabled.
- Select required checks: `lint`, `typecheck`, `build`, `test` (optionally `audit`).
- **Block force pushes** and **Restrict deletions** → enabled.
- **Require linear history** and **Require signed commits** → enabled per your policy.
- Allow only **Squash** and **Rebase** merge methods for a clean history.

---

## Rollout Plan
1. Create the workflow in a short-lived branch (`ci/bootstrap-ci`).
2. Open a PR → confirm checks run and finish within the target time.
3. Add the checks as **required** in the Ruleset (once they’re green).
4. Merge the PR.
5. Monitor subsequent PRs for false positives or performance issues.
6. Iterate: add/remove optional checks (e.g., `audit`, `sizelimit`).

---

## Risks & Mitigations
- **Slow CI**: Keep jobs parallel, cache dependencies, limit paths.
- **Flaky tests**: Start with unit tests; quarantine flaky suites.
- **Overly strict audit**: Start non-blocking; later make it required.
- **Missing scripts**: Add minimal `lint`, `build`, `test` scripts in `package.json`.

---

## Metrics / Success Criteria
- Median PR CI duration **≤ 10 minutes**.
- 100% of merged PRs have all required checks green.
- Zero unintended releases from PR pipelines.
- Reduced post-merge failures on `main` (track incidents/regressions).

---

## Definition of Done
- `.github/workflows/ci.yml` present and running on PRs.
- Ruleset updated with selected jobs as required checks.
- Documentation (this file) linked in the governance system/task.
- Example PR demonstrating green checks.

---

## Governance Task Creation (example)

**Title**: Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for `main`  
**Priority**: High  
**Tags**: `ci`, `quality`, `governance`

### Create via CLI (using a temp file in /tmp)
```bash
cat > /tmp/ci-task.md << 'EOF'
# (Paste this whole document content here)
EOF

gitgov task new "Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for main" \
  --description-file /tmp/ci-task.md \
  --priority high \
  --tags ci,quality,governance \
  --cleanup-file

# Then follow workflow:
gitgov task submit <task-id>    # send for review
gitgov task approve <task-id>   # approve definition
gitgov task activate <task-id>  # start implementation
```

# Remove Kiro-related Files and References

## Summary
Clean up the monorepo by removing all Kiro-related files, directories, and references that are no longer needed for the GitGovernance project.

## Background
Kiro was a previous iteration or companion tool that is no longer part of the GitGovernance ecosystem. The `.kiro/` directory and various references throughout the codebase should be removed to:
- Reduce repository clutter
- Prevent confusion for new contributors
- Maintain focus on GitGovernance core functionality
- Clean up historical artifacts

## Scope

### Files to Remove
1. **`.kiro/` directory** (entire directory tree)
   - `.kiro/hooks/` - All hook files and documentation
   - `.kiro/specs/` - All specification files
   - `.kiro/steering/` - All steering documents

2. **References in documentation/blueprints** (case-insensitive search)
   - Files mentioning "kiro" in `packages/blueprints/`
   - Files mentioning "kiro" in other documentation

### What NOT to Remove
- Any Kiro references that are purely historical context in changelogs
- Any third-party dependencies or libraries that happen to contain "kiro" in their name

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All `.kiro/` directories and files are deleted
- [ ] `git status` shows no untracked Kiro-related files
- [ ] Repository builds successfully after cleanup
- [ ] No linter errors introduced by removal
- [ ] `.gitignore` does not need Kiro-specific entries (or they are removed)

```bash
git rm -rf .kiro/
```

### Step 2: Review blueprint references (optional)

- Note: Most blueprint references are likely historical and can remain

```bash

pnpm test --workspaces
```

### Step 5: Commit and push
```bash
git add -A
git commit -m "chore: remove Kiro-related files and directory

- Remove .kiro/ directory (hooks, specs, steering)
- Clean up legacy tooling artifacts
- No functional changes to GitGovernance core"
```

## Risks & Mitigations
- **Risk**: Accidentally removing needed files
  - **Mitigation**: Use `git rm` so changes are tracked and reversible
- **Risk**: Breaking build due to missing dependencies
  - **Mitigation**: Run full build and test suite before committing

## Release Impact
**Type**: chore → No version bump (cleanup only)
**Scope**: repo → Changes at repository level, no package changes

## Definition of Done
- `.kiro/` directory completely removed from repository
- No new linter errors or build failures
- Changes committed and merged to `main`

payload.title: Rename types/ directory to models/ for improved semantic clarity
payload.description:
# Rename types/ Directory to models/ for Improved Semantic Clarity

## Context

The `packages/core/src/types/` directory contains TypeScript type definitions and data models for GitGovernance records (TaskRecord, ActorRecord, CycleRecord, etc.). While functional, the name "types" is ambiguous and doesn't clearly convey that these are **domain data models**.

## Problem

1. **Semantic Ambiguity**: "types" could mean generic TypeScript utility types vs. domain models
2. **Industry Convention**: Most frameworks use "models" (Django, Rails, NestJS, Laravel)
3. **Confusion with schemas/**: Not immediately clear that `types/` = compile-time, `schemas/` = runtime
4. **Onboarding Friction**: New developers need extra context to understand the distinction

## Solution

Rename `packages/core/src/types/` → `packages/core/src/models/` with cascading import updates.

### Files to Rename
- `types/` → `models/`
- `types/index.ts` → `models/index.ts`
