# Universe View: Interactive Knowledge Graph for GitGovernance

## 🎯 Overview

Build an interactive, immersive knowledge graph visualization that allows navigation across all GitGovernance protocols (tasks, cycles, executions, feedback, changelog, agents) with real-time updates, advanced filtering, and temporal playback capabilities.

**Goal**: Replace static Mermaid diagrams with a scalable, multi-dimensional project visualization tool that enables teams to visualize project evolution over time, identify bottlenecks, track agent activity in real-time, and navigate complex relationships between entities at scale (1000+ nodes).

---

## ✅ Acceptance Criteria

### Must Have (MVP - Phase 1)

- [ ] **Data Loading**: Load and parse tasks + cycles from 
- [ ] **Basic Graph Rendering**: Display nodes (tasks, cycles) and edges (relationships) using force-directed layout
- [ ] **Visual Encoding**:
  - Tasks as rectangles with size proportional to complexity
  - Cycles as rounded containers
  - Color coding by status (draft=gray, ready=yellow, active=blue, done=green, blocked=red, archived=light-gray)
- [ ] **Interactivity**:
  - Click on node → Show detailed sidebar with full entity data
  - Hover on node → Highlight direct relationships
  - Zoom and pan navigation
  - Drag nodes to reorganize
- [ ] **Basic Filters**:
  - Filter by status (draft, ready, active, done, blocked, archived)
  - Filter by priority (low, medium, high, critical)
  - Filter by entity type (task, cycle)
- [ ] **Performance**: Render up to 500 nodes without lag (<100ms render time)

### Should Have (Phase 2 - Multiprotocolo)

- [ ] **Extended Data Loading**: Load executions, feedback, changelog from 
- [ ] **Multi-Entity Visualization**:
  - Executions as activity pulses on tasks
  - Feedback as halos around entities (color by status: open=orange, resolved=green)
  - Changelog as temporal trails showing history
  - Agents as animated avatars moving between tasks
- [ ] **Relationship Types**:
  - Dependencies (solid lines)
  - Blockers (red pulsing lines)
  - Cycle containment (orbital grouping)
  - Feedback threads (conversation lines)
  - Execution history (activity trails)
- [ ] **Advanced Filters**:
  - Filter by date range
  - Filter by actor (assignee, creator)
  - Filter by tags
  - Filter by relationship type
  - Combined filters with AND/OR logic
- [ ] **Timeline View**: Alternative layout showing entities on temporal axis

### Could Have (Phase 3 - Real-time & Analytics)

- [ ] **Real-time Updates**: WebSocket/SSE integration for live updates when entities change
- [ ] **Visual Analytics**:
  - Heatmap overlay showing activity density
  - Critical path highlighting (longest dependency chain)
  - Bottleneck detection (nodes with most blockers)
  - Agent workload visualization (tasks per agent)
  - Stale entity detection (no activity in N days)
- [ ] **Search & Navigation**:
  - Full-text search across all entities
  - Auto-zoom to search results
  - Breadcrumb navigation for complex paths
- [ ] **Export**: Export current view as SVG/PNG

### Nice to Have (Phase 4 - Immersive Experience)

- [ ] **Time Travel**: Playback slider to see project evolution over time
- [ ] **3D View**: Optional 3D force-directed graph using Three.js

enrichedTasks.title: Reorganize protocol folder numbering to reflect logical dependencies
enrichedTasks.description:
# Reorganize protocol folder numbering to reflect logical dependencies

## Problem

The current folder order in `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/` does not reflect the conceptual and logical dependencies between protocols:

**Current Order:**
```
01_embedded
02_actor
03_agent
04_task
06_execution
07_changelog
08_feedback
05_cycle
09_workflow_methodology
10_planning_methodology
12_persistence
13_metrics
99_appendices
```

**Issues:**
- `05_cycle` should come before `06_execution` because it defines the temporal/strategic context
- `cycle` groups `tasks`, so conceptually it should come before execution records
- Current order makes onboarding difficult for new developers
- Does not reflect the logical implementation sequence

## Proposed Solution

Reorder folders following conceptual dependencies:

**New Order:**
```
01_embedded          (technical foundation - metadata structure)
02_actor             (identities - who signs/works)
03_agent             (specific AI agents)
04_task              (what to do - atomic unit of work)
05_cycle             (when/how to group - sprint/milestone)
06_execution         (progress tracking on tasks)
07_changelog         (compiled history)
08_feedback          (continuous improvement)
09_workflow_methodology
10_planning_methodology
11_persistence       (currently 12)
12_metrics           (currently 13)
99_appendices
```

## Rationale

1. **Task before Cycle**: Tasks can exist without cycles (`cycleIds` is optional), but Cycles group Tasks
2. **Cycle before Execution**: First define WHAT and WHEN (task + cycle), then record work (execution)
3. **Persistence before Metrics**: Metrics depend on how data is persisted

## Specific Tasks

1. Rename folders while keeping content intact:
   - `05_cycle` → `05_cycle`
   - `06_execution` → `06_execution`
   - `07_changelog` → `07_changelog`
   - `08_feedback` → `08_feedback`
   - `12_persistence` → `11_persistence`
   - `13_metrics` → `12_metrics`

2. Update cross-references in documentation:
   - Search for old path references
   - Update imports/links in other protocols
   - Verify examples still work

3. Update scripts/tooling that depend on these paths (if any)

## Impact

- **Low risk**: Only folder name changes, no content changes
- **High benefit**: Better system understanding for new contributors
- **Documentation**: More intuitive and easier to follow sequentially

## References

- Discussion about logical order vs functional implementation
- System currently functional without cycle/execution/feedback fully implemented
- Need to improve developer experience and onboarding

# Implementar CLI Commands del Feedback Protocol

## Contexto

El `FeedbackAdapter` core está completo (6/6 métodos, patrón inmutable). El blueprint `feedback_command.md` está completamente documentado con 5 comandos y 20 EARS, pero **ningún comando CLI está implementado** aún.

Los comandos `gitgov feedback` no existen. El sistema depende de que los usuarios usen el adapter programáticamente o vía `gitgov task assign` (que usa el adapter internamente).

- No hay forma de crear feedback blocking desde CLI
- No hay forma de crear feedback question desde CLI
- No hay forma de ver threads de conversación
- Workflow de comunicación estructurada está incompleto

Implementar los 5 comandos CLI documentados en `feedback_command.md`:

### 1. `gitgov feedback create`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/create.ts`

**Funcionalidad:**
- Validar entity existe
- Crear FeedbackRecord vía FeedbackAdapter
- Emitir evento para side effects
- Output formateado (no-json mode)

### 2. `gitgov feedback list`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/list.ts`

**Archivo:** `packages/cli/src/commands/feedback/reply.ts`

# Review absolute coherence of all Protocols and READMEs for v1.0.0 release

## Context

After completing individual protocol reviews (Execution, Feedback, Changelog, Task, Cycle, WorkflowMethodology, PlanningMethodology) following the 5-layer verification process, we need a **final cross-protocol review** to ensure absolute coherence across ALL protocols before declaring version 1.0.0 stable.

This task is the **final quality gate** before freezing the Protocol v1.0.0 specification.

## Objective

Perform a comprehensive cross-protocol coherence review to certify that:
1. All protocols follow the same documentation standard
2. Cross-references between protocols are accurate
3. READMEs provide correct navigation
4. Terminology is consistent across all protocols
5. Examples reference valid entities from other protocols
6. Schema generation works for ALL protocols
7. No orphaned or contradictory documentation

## Protocols to Review (9 Total)

### Core Data Protocols (6)
1. ✅ **Task Protocol** - Already reviewed and coherent
2. ✅ **Cycle Protocol** - Already reviewed and coherent
3. ⚠️ **Execution Protocol** - Docs reviewed, code pending (Task 1761604438)
4. ⚠️ **Feedback Protocol** - Complete (Task 1761603296 for final tests)
5. ⚠️ **Changelog Protocol** - Docs reviewed, code pending (Task 1761604451)
6. ✅ **Actor Protocol** - Used as reference, assumed coherent

### Configuration Protocols (2)
7. ⚠️ **WorkflowMethodology Protocol** - Pending review (Task 1761604701)
8. ⚠️ **PlanningMethodology Protocol** - Pending review (Task 1761604714)

### Infrastructure Protocol (1)
9. ✅ **EmbeddedMetadata Protocol** - Used as base, assumed coherent

## Work Scope

### 1. Cross-Protocol Reference Validation

**Verify all cross-references are valid:**

```bash
# Example checks:
# In feedback_protocol.md:
- References to task_protocol.md → ¿Valid path? ¿Section exists?
- References to execution_protocol.md → ¿Coherent?

# In execution_protocol.md:
- References to task_protocol.md → ¿Bidirectional?
- Examples use valid task IDs → ¿Format correct?

# In changelog_protocol.md:
- References to task_protocol.md → ¿Coherent with new 12-field schema?
```

**Files to check:**

- ❓ Provides correct navigation links
- ❓ Describes purpose of each protocol
- ❓ Version information (v1.0.0)
- ❓ Getting started guide

**Verify:**
- ❓ Consistent structure across all protocols
- ❓ Links to related protocols
- ❓ Links to adapters
- ❓ Links to CLI commands

### 3. Terminology Consistency

**Verify same concepts use same terms across protocols:**

| Concept | Standard Term | Check Across |
|:---|:---|:---|
| Create new record | `create` (not `add`) | All protocols |

# Translate Protocol Documentation: Design i18n structure and implement English version

## Context

All GitGovernance protocols are currently documented in **Spanish**. To make the project accessible to the global developer community, we need to:
1. Design the internationalization (i18n) structure
2. Translate all protocols to English
3. Maintain both versions going forward

This is critical for open-source adoption and international collaboration.

## Problem

**Current state:**
- ✅ 9 protocols fully documented in Spanish
- ❌ No English version available
- ❌ No i18n structure defined
- ❌ No process for maintaining translations

**Impact:**
- Non-Spanish developers cannot understand the protocol
- Open-source contributions limited
- International adoption blocked

## Solution - i18n Structure Design

### Option A: Language Subdirectories (RECOMMENDED)

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/
├── es/  ← Spanish (original)
│   ├── 01_embedded/
│   │   ├── embedded_metadata_protocol.md
│   │   └── embedded_metadata_schema.yaml
│   ├── 04_task/
│   │   ├── task_protocol.md
│   │   ├── task_protocol_faq.md
│   │   └── task_record_schema.yaml
│   └── ...
├── en/  ← English (translated)
│   ├── 01_embedded/
│   │   ├── embedded_metadata_protocol.md
│   │   └── embedded_metadata_schema.yaml  ← Same (no translation needed)
│   ├── 04_task/
│   │   ├── task_protocol.md
│   │   ├── task_protocol_faq.md
│   │   └── task_record_schema.yaml  ← Same
│   └── ...
└── README.md  ← Bilingual navigation
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ Clean separation
- ✅ Easy to add more languages (pt/, fr/, etc.)
- ✅ Default language configurable
- ✅ Schemas shared (no duplication)

**Disadvantages:**
- ⚠️ Duplication of schemas (or symlinks needed)
- ⚠️ Cross-references need language-aware paths

### Option B: Suffix-Based Files

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/
├── 04_task/
│   ├── task_protocol.es.md  ← Spanish
│   ├── task_protocol.en.md  ← English
│   ├── task_protocol_faq.es.md
│   ├── task_protocol_faq.en.md
│   └── task_record_schema.yaml  ← Shared (no translation)
└── ...
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ Schemas stay in same directory
- ✅ Easy to see translation status (missing .en.md files)

**Disadvantages:**
- ⚠️ Directory clutter (2x files)
- ⚠️ Harder to maintain consistency

### Option C: Separate Repo/Package for Translations

```
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/  ← Spanish (source of truth)
packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol-en/  ← English (separate)
```

**Advantages:**
- ✅ No impact on original structure
- ✅ Can have different maintainers

**Disadvantages:**
- ❌ Hard to keep in sync
- ❌ Schemas duplicated

### Recommended: Option A (Language Subdirectories)

**Implementation:**

1. Create `/es/` and `/en/` directories
2. Move current Spanish docs to `/es/`
3. Keep schemas in both (or symlink to `/es/`)
4. Translate to `/en/`
5. Update `pnpm sync:schemas` to handle both languages

## Scope of Work

### Phase 1: Structure Design (1-2 hours)

**Decisions needed:**
- Choose Option A, B, or C
- Define schema handling (duplicate vs symlink)
- Define cross-reference format for i18n
- Update build scripts (`sync:schemas`, `compile:types`)

### Phase 2: Move Current Spanish Docs (2-3 hours)

**Tasks:**
- Create `/es/` directory structure
- Move all `*_protocol.md` files to `/es/`
- Move all `*_protocol_faq.md` files to `/es/`
- Decide schema location (keep in `/es/` or root)
- Update all internal cross-references
- Verify `pnpm sync:schemas` still works

### Phase 3: Translate to English (2-3 weeks)

**9 Protocols to translate:**

| Protocol | Files to Translate | Estimated Lines | Time |
|:---|:---|---:|:---:|
| EmbeddedMetadata | protocol.md | ~200 | 2h |
| Actor | protocol.md + FAQ | ~300 | 3h |
| Agent | protocol.md | ~200 | 2h |
| Task | protocol.md + FAQ | ~450 | 4h |
| Cycle | protocol.md + FAQ | ~350 | 3h |
| Execution | protocol.md + appendix + FAQ | ~600 | 6h |
| Changelog | protocol.md + FAQ | ~400 | 4h |
| Feedback | protocol.md + FAQ | ~500 | 5h |
| WorkflowMethodology | protocol.md | ~400 | 4h |
| PlanningMethodology | protocol.md (if exists) | ~300 | 3h |

**Total:** ~3,700 lines, ~36 hours of translation work

**Translation quality requirements:**
- Technical accuracy (preserve meaning)
- Consistent terminology
- Professional tone
- Code examples stay in English
- YAML schemas unchanged

### Phase 4: Bilingual README (1-2 hours)

**Create:** `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/README.md`

**Content:**
```markdown
# GitGovernance Protocols / Protocolos GitGovernance

[English](#english) | [Español](#español)

## English

GitGovernance defines 9 core protocols...

**Available Protocols:**
- [Embedded Metadata](en/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_protocol.md)
- [Task Protocol](en/04_task/task_protocol.md)
- ...

## Español

GitGovernance define 9 protocolos core...

**Protocolos Disponibles:**
- [Metadatos Embebidos](es/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_protocol.md)
- [Protocolo de Tareas](es/04_task/task_protocol.md)
- ...
```

### Phase 5: Update Build Scripts (2-3 hours)

**Update:** `packages/core/scripts/sync-schemas.ts`

**Changes needed:**
```typescript
// Support both /es/ and /en/ paths
const PROTOCOL_DIRS = [
  '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/es/',
  '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/en/'  // If schemas duplicated
];

// Or: Only sync from /es/ (source of truth)
const PROTOCOL_DIR = '../blueprints/03_products/protocol/es/';
```

## Deliverables

1. ✅ i18n structure decision document
2. ✅ `/es/` directory with all Spanish docs
3. ✅ `/en/` directory with all English translations
4. ✅ Bilingual main README
5. ✅ Updated build scripts supporting i18n
6. ✅ Translation consistency guide
7. ✅ Verification: schemas generate from both languages

## Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ i18n structure implemented (Option A, B, or C)
2. ✅ All Spanish docs moved to `/es/` (or renamed with .es.md)
3. ✅ All 9 protocols translated to English
4. ✅ Technical terminology consistent across translations
5. ✅ Code examples preserved correctly
6. ✅ Bilingual README with clear navigation
7. ✅ Build scripts work with new structure
8. ✅ `pnpm sync:schemas` generates schemas correctly
9. ✅ Cross-references work in both languages

## Translation Strategy

### Terminology Dictionary (to maintain consistency)

| Spanish | English | Notes |
|:---|:---|:---|
| Tarea | Task | Core entity |
| Ciclo | Cycle | Strategic planning |
| Ejecución | Execution | Work chronicle |
| Retroalimentación | Feedback | Structured communication |
| Registro de Cambios | Changelog | Release notes |

### Translation Tools

**Options:**
1. **Manual** - High quality, time-consuming
2. **AI-assisted** - Fast, needs review
3. **Hybrid** - AI first draft + human review (RECOMMENDED)

**Quality check:**
- Technical reviewer (bilingual developer)
- Consistency validator (terminology)
- Cross-reference tester

## Dependencies

**Bloqueado por:**
- Task 1761604438 (ExecutionAdapter verification)
- Task 1761604451 (ChangelogAdapter verification)
- Task 1761604701 (WorkflowMethodology verification)
- Task 1761604714 (PlanningMethodology verification)
- Previous task (v1.0.0 coherence review)

**Reason:** Protocols must be 100% coherent in Spanish before translating to avoid translating inconsistencies.

## Estimation

**Complexity:** Medium (translation work, structure design)
**Time:** 
- Structure design + migration: 1 day
- Translation (9 protocols): 2-3 weeks
- Review + fixes: 3-5 days
- **Total:** 3-4 weeks
**Priority:** Medium (important for adoption, not blocking current work)
**Risk:** Low (mostly documentation work)

enrichedTasks.description:
# Fix Missing `notes` Field in Signature Objects Across Tests

## Problem

Multiple test files (31 tests failing) are creating signature objects that don't comply with `embedded_metadata_schema.yaml`. The schema requires the `notes` field in all signature objects, but many tests omit it.

### Schema Requirement (embedded_metadata_schema.yaml:55-59)

```yaml
notes:
  type: string
  minLength: 1
  maxLength: 1000
  description: "Human-readable note from the signer. Part of the signature digest."
```

**Required fields:** keyId, role, **notes**, signature, timestamp, timestamp_iso

### Current Violations

**Example from CLI tests:**
```typescript
// ❌ INVALID (missing notes)
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test-user',
  role: 'creator',
  timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
  signature: 'test-signature'
}]
```

**Example from Core validators:**
```typescript
// ❌ INVALID (missing notes)
signatures: [{ 
  keyId: 'human:test', 
  role: 'author', 
  signature: 'sig', 
  timestamp: 123, 
  timestamp_iso: '' 
}]
```

### Affected Files (28 total)

**Core package (25 files):**
- `packages/core/src/validation/*.test.ts` (9 files)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/*/index.ts` (5 files)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/*/*.test.ts` (10 files)
- `packages/core/src/crypto/signatures.test.ts`
- `packages/core/src/store/record_store.test.ts`

**CLI package (3 files):**
- `packages/cli/e2e/task_command_e2e.test.ts`
- `packages/cli/e2e/dashboard_command_e2e.test.ts`
- `packages/cli/e2e/diagram_command_e2e.test.ts`

## Solution

### Step 1: Audit All Signature Objects

Search for all occurrences of `signatures: [` in:
- `packages/core/src/**/*.ts`
- `packages/cli/**/*.ts`

### Step 2: Add Missing `notes` Field

For each signature object, add the required `notes` field:

```typescript
// ✅ VALID
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test-user',
  role: 'creator',
  notes: 'Test signature for unit testing',  // 👈 ADD THIS
  timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
  signature: 'test-signature'
}]
```

**Guidelines for `notes` content:**
- **Production code:** Use descriptive notes explaining the signature context
- **Test code:** Use `''` (empty string) or simple descriptions like `'Test signature'`
- **Examples (from schema):** Follow patterns in embedded_metadata_schema.yaml lines 190, 209, 215, 234, 240

### Step 3: Special Cases

**Case A: Type-casting signatures (tests)**
```typescript
// ✅ Ensure all fields present before casting
signatures: [{
  keyId: 'human:test',
  role: 'author',
  notes: '',  // Required even for test mocks
  signature: 'sig',
  timestamp: 123,
  timestamp_iso: '2025-01-01T00:00:00Z'
}] as [Signature, ...Signature[]]
```

**Case B: Dynamic signature creation**
```typescript
// ✅ Ensure factory functions include notes
const signature = {
  keyId: actorId,
  role: 'author',
  notes: '',  // Default for generated signatures
  signature: 'placeholder',
  timestamp: Date.now(),
  timestamp_iso: new Date().toISOString()
}
```

### Step 4: Verify TypeScript Compliance

After changes, verify:
```bash
cd packages/core && npx tsc --noEmit
cd packages/cli && npx tsc --noEmit
```

### Step 5: Run Tests

```bash
cd packages/core && pnpm test
cd packages/cli && pnpm test:e2e
```

## Acceptance Criteria

1. ✅ All signature objects include the `notes` field
2. ✅ TypeScript compiles without errors
3. ✅ All tests pass (currently 728 passing → 759 passing)
4. ✅ No implicit `any` types remain
5. ✅ Schema compliance verified in all production code

## References

- **Schema:** `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/01_embedded/embedded_metadata_schema.yaml`
- **Examples:** Lines 188-249 in schema (shows proper `notes` usage)
- **Related Issue:** This blocks proper signature verification in production

## Estimated Effort

- **Complexity:** Low (mechanical changes)
- **Time:** 1-2 hours (28 files to update)
- **Risk:** Low (purely additive change)

# Wrap WorkflowMethodologyRecord in EmbeddedMetadata

## Context
Currently `WorkflowMethodologyRecord` is stored as plain YAML config without audit trail, signatures, or versioning. This creates an architectural inconsistency with all other Records and lacks governance controls.

## Problem
- No signature verification for methodology changes
- No audit trail of who modified what and when
- No checksum integrity validation
- Inconsistent architecture (only Record type not wrapped in EmbeddedMetadata)

## Proposed Solution
Wrap `WorkflowMethodologyRecord` in `EmbeddedMetadata` (like all other 7 Records) to enable:
1. **Signature verification** for methodology changes
2. **Audit trail** of modifications (who, when, what)
3. **Checksum integrity** validation
4. **Consistent architecture** across all Records

## Technical Scope

### Files to Modify/Create (~12-15 files)
1. **Validator** (~30 lines)
   - Add `validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord` with EARS 1-4
   - Update tests with EARS 1-4 coverage

2. **Factory** (new file ~80 lines)
   - Create `createWorkflowMethodologyRecord`
   - Uses `createEmbeddedMetadataRecord` internally
   - Full test coverage

3. **ConfigManager** (~50 lines)
   - Backward compatibility for existing YAML files
   - Detect format (old vs new)
   - Handle both transparently

4. **CLI** (~40 lines)
   - Auto-wrap on save
   - Auto-unwrap on load
   - Maintain UX consistency

5. **Integration Tests** (new file ~100 lines)
   - Test migration path
   - Test backward compatibility
   - Test new workflow

## Challenges

### 🔴 CRITICAL: Backward Compatibility
- Existing `.gitgov/workflow_methodology.yaml` files must continue working without changes
- ConfigManager must detect format and handle both
- Migration must be transparent to users

### Strategy
```typescript
// ConfigManager: Detect format
function loadWorkflowMethodology(): WorkflowMethodologyRecord {
  const raw = readYAML('.gitgov/workflow_methodology.yaml');
  
  // New format: has header + payload
  if (raw.header && raw.payload) {
    await validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord(raw, getPublicKey);
    return raw.payload;
  }
  
  // Old format: plain config
  validateWorkflowMethodologyConfigDetailed(raw);
  return raw;
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `validateFullWorkflowMethodologyRecord` implements EARS 1-4
- [ ] Factory creates properly signed `WorkflowMethodologyRecord`
- [ ] ConfigManager loads both old and new formats transparently
- [ ] CLI wraps on save, unwraps on load
- [ ] All existing projects continue working without changes
- [ ] Integration tests cover migration path (old → new)
- [ ] Documentation updated (blueprint + CLI docs)
- [ ] All 133+ existing tests continue passing

## Estimated Effort
**2-3 days** of focused work (~17-20 hours)

## References
- `validator_module.md` - Generic EARS 1-16 specification
- `execution_validator.ts` - Reference implementation for Records with EmbeddedMetadata
- `task_validator.ts` - Another reference implementation
- `workflow_methodology_validator.ts` - Current implementation (no EmbeddedMetadata)

## Tags

## Priority
Medium (Important for architecture consistency, but existing system works)

El método `getFeedbackByEntity()` en `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts` (líneas 244-256) ejecuta las lecturas **secuencialmente**:

```typescript
async getFeedbackByEntity(entityId: string): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  const feedbacks: FeedbackRecord[] = [];

  // ❌ PROBLEMA: Loop secuencial - espera cada await antes de continuar
  for (const id of ids) {
    const record = await this.feedbackStore.read(id);
    if (record && record.payload.entityId === entityId) {
      feedbacks.push(record.payload);
    }
  }

  return feedbacks;
}
```

**Por qué es lento:**
- Con 1200 feedbacks en el test, ejecuta 1200 llamadas `await` secuenciales
- Cada llamada espera a que la anterior termine antes de iniciar
- Tiempo total = suma de todos los tiempos de lectura individuales
- Resultado: 128ms (excede el límite de 100ms)

### Problema Secundario: `getAllFeedback()` Tiene el Mismo Patrón

El método `getAllFeedback()` (líneas 266-278) usa el mismo patrón secuencial ineficiente:

```typescript
async getAllFeedback(): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  const feedbacks: FeedbackRecord[] = [];

  // ❌ Mismo problema de performance
  for (const id of ids) {
    const record = await this.feedbackStore.read(id);
    if (record) {
      feedbacks.push(record.payload);
    }
  }

  return feedbacks;
}
```

## ✅ Solución Propuesta: Paralelización con Promise.all()

### Para `getFeedbackByEntity()`:

```typescript
async getFeedbackByEntity(entityId: string): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  
  // ✅ SOLUCIÓN: Ejecutar todas las lecturas en paralelo
  const records = await Promise.all(
    ids.map(id => this.feedbackStore.read(id))
  );
  
  // Filtrar y extraer payloads
  return records
    .filter(record => record && record.payload.entityId === entityId)
    .map(record => record!.payload);
}
```

### Para `getAllFeedback()`:

```typescript
async getAllFeedback(): Promise<FeedbackRecord[]> {
  const ids = await this.feedbackStore.list();
  
  // ✅ Paralelización
  const records = await Promise.all(
    ids.map(id => this.feedbackStore.read(id))
  );
  
  // Filtrar nulos y extraer payloads
  return records
    .filter(record => record !== null)
    .map(record => record!.payload);
}
```

## 📈 Mejora de Performance Esperada

- **Antes (secuencial):** ~128ms para 1200 feedbacks
- **Después (paralelo):** ~10-50ms para 1200 feedbacks (dependiendo del mock)
- **Reducción esperada:** 60-87% menos tiempo
- **Test EARS-29:** ✅ Debería pasar (<100ms)

## 🎯 Cambios a Realizar

### Archivo: `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts`

1. **Modificar `getFeedbackByEntity()` (líneas 244-256)**
   - Reemplazar el loop `for...of` secuencial
   - Implementar `Promise.all()` con `.map()`
   - Usar encadenamiento funcional con `.filter()` y `.map()`

2. **Modificar `getAllFeedback()` (líneas 266-278)**
   - Aplicar el mismo patrón de paralelización
   - Mantener la lógica de filtrado de nulos

### Archivo de Tests: `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts`

**NO requiere cambios** - El test está correctamente implementado y pasará automáticamente al optimizar el código.

## 📋 Criterios de Aceptación

1. ✅ Test `[EARS-29] should filter 1000+ feedbacks in under 100ms` debe pasar
2. ✅ Todos los tests existentes de `FeedbackAdapter` deben seguir pasando (45 tests, 1024 passed)
3. ✅ Performance mejorada sin cambiar la API pública (sin breaking changes)
4. ✅ Mantener el comportamiento funcional idéntico (solo optimización interna)
5. ✅ Código más legible usando paradigma funcional (map/filter)

## 🔗 Referencias

### Archivos Afectados:
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts` (implementación)
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/feedback_adapter.test.ts` (test que valida el fix)

### Documentación:
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/adapters/feedback_adapter.md`:
  - **Línea 434:** Definición de EARS-29 (requisito de performance)
  - **Línea 481:** Estado de implementación del test (actualmente ❌)

### EARS Relacionados:
- **EARS-29:** Debe filtrar 1000+ feedbacks en <100ms
- **EARS-28:** Debe ejecutarse en <50ms para datasets típicos
- **EARS-30:** Debe construir thread de 20+ niveles en <200ms (no afectado por este cambio)

## 🏷️ Metadata

- **Tipo:** Bug Fix (Performance)
- **Prioridad:** High (afecta test suite)
- **Complejidad:** Baja (cambio algorítmico simple, 2 métodos)
- **Impacto:** Performance crítica para sistemas con muchos feedbacks
- **Tiempo Estimado:** 15-30 minutos
- **Testing:** Automático (test existente valida el fix)

## 🚀 Estrategia de Implementación

1. **Modificar `getFeedbackByEntity()`:**
   - Reemplazar loop secuencial por `Promise.all()`
   - Usar encadenamiento funcional

2. **Modificar `getAllFeedback()`:**
   - Aplicar mismo patrón de paralelización

3. **Verificar Tests:**
   ```bash
   cd packages/core
   pnpm test feedback_adapter.test.ts
   ```

4. **Validar Suite Completa:**
   ```bash
   pnpm test
   ```

5. **Verificar Blueprint:**
   - Actualizar estado de EARS-29 en tabla de trazabilidad (línea 481)
   - Cambiar ❌ por ✅ en el estado de implementación

## 💡 Notas Adicionales

- Este patrón de paralelización es común en Node.js para I/O operations
- No hay riesgo de race conditions ya que las lecturas son operaciones independientes
- El método `buildThread()` (líneas 295-336) también usa loops secuenciales pero es correcto porque necesita construir el árbol recursivamente respetando el orden
- La optimización solo aplica cuando las operaciones son completamente independientes entre sí

# Agregar dependencia faltante `dotenv` a @gitgov/core

## 📋 Contexto

Durante una auditoría exhaustiva de dependencias en `packages/core` usando el protocolo `@dependency-auditor-agent`, se detectó una **dependencia faltante crítica**.

## 🔍 Problema Detectado

El archivo `packages/core/jest.env.js` utiliza `dotenv` pero no está declarado en `package.json`:

```javascript
// packages/core/jest.env.js:1
const { config } = require('dotenv');
```

**Evidencia de búsqueda:**
```bash
grep -r "require\(['\"']dotenv['\"']\)" packages/core/
# Result: packages/core/jest.env.js:1
```

**Estado actual:** La dependencia NO existe en `dependencies` ni en `devDependencies`.

## ✅ Solución Propuesta

Agregar `dotenv` como `devDependency` ya que solo se usa en el entorno de testing:

```bash
cd packages/core
pnpm add -D dotenv
```

## 🎯 Clasificación

- **Tipo de uso:** Configuración de entorno de testing (jest.env.js)
- **Clasificación correcta:** `devDependencies` (no se necesita en runtime de producción)
- **Prioridad:** Media (el proyecto funciona actualmente, posiblemente por hoisting de pnpm workspace)

## 🧪 Validación Post-Cambio

Después de agregar la dependencia, verificar:

```bash
cd packages/core

# 1. Reinstalar dependencias
pnpm install

# 2. Verificar compilación TypeScript
npx tsc --noEmit

# 3. Ejecutar tests
pnpm test
```

## 📊 Resultado de Auditoría Completa

**Dependencias auditadas:** 17 total (3 production, 14 development)
- ✅ Correctamente clasificadas: 16
- ❌ Faltantes: 1 (`dotenv`)
- ✅ Sin uso: 0
- ✅ Mal clasificadas: 0

**Conclusión:** El proyecto tiene una gestión de dependencias excelente, solo falta agregar esta única dependencia.

## 🔗 Referencias

- Archivo afectado: `packages/core/jest.env.js`
- Package.json: `packages/core/package.json`
- Protocolo usado: `docs/dependency_auditor_agent_prompt.md`

# Persist Actor Private Keys to Disk

## Problem

Currently, when creating an ActorRecord via `gitgov init`, the private key is generated but:
- ❌ Only displayed once in the terminal (can be lost)
- ❌ Not persisted to disk
- ✅ `.gitignore` already configured for `.gitgov/actors/*.key`

This means users cannot sign records after initialization unless they saved the key manually.

## Solution

Modify `IdentityAdapter.createActor()` to persist private keys:

1. Save private key to `.gitgov/actors/{actorId}.key` (base64 format)
2. Set file permissions to `0600` (owner read/write only)
3. Load private key when needed for signing operations
4. Update documentation about key management

## Implementation Notes

- File: `packages/core/src/adapters/identity_adapter/index.ts`
- Already gitignored: `.gitgov/actors/*.key`
- Format: Base64-encoded PKCS8 PEM (current privateKey format)
- Security: File permissions `0600` (Node.js `fs.chmod`)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Private key saved to `.gitgov/actors/{actorId}.key` on actor creation
- [ ] File has secure permissions (0600)
- [ ] Key can be loaded for signing operations
- [ ] Tests verify key persistence and loading
- [ ] Documentation updated with key management guidelines

# Translate Spanish Task Titles to English

## Problem

Currently, some TaskRecords have titles in Spanish, which may cause:
- Inconsistency in the task backlog
- Difficulty for English-speaking contributors
- Mixed language in reports and dashboards

## Solution

Create a script/workflow to:

1. List all active tasks (status != done, status != archived)
2. Detect which tasks have Spanish titles
3. Translate ONLY the title to English (keep description as-is)
4. Update the task using `gitgov task edit`

## Implementation Notes

**Detection Strategy:**
- Use language detection (e.g., check for Spanish words like "implementar", "crear", "añadir", "mejorar")
- Or use a simple heuristic (accented characters: á, é, í, ó, ú, ñ)

**Translation:**
- Can use AI translation (OpenAI, Claude, etc.)
- Or manual translation for small backlog

**Update Method:**
```bash
# For each Spanish task:
gitgov task edit <task-id> --title "New English Title"
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Script lists all non-done, non-archived tasks
- [ ] Detects Spanish titles accurately
- [ ] Translates titles preserving technical meaning
- [ ] Updates tasks using proper CLI commands
- [ ] Preserves all other task metadata (description, tags, status, etc.)
- [ ] Reports which tasks were translated

Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for main
enrichedTasks.description:
# Task: Establish CI Pipeline and Required Checks for `main`

## Summary
Create a lightweight but reliable Continuous Integration (CI) workflow that runs on every Pull Request targeting `main`. The workflow must validate code quality and prevent risky merges by enforcing **required checks** in a GitHub Ruleset.

This document is intended to be used as a long description when creating a governance task (e.g., with `--description-file /tmp/ci-task.md`).

---

## Objectives
1. **Prevent broken code** from being merged into `main`.
2. **Provide fast feedback** to contributors (target: < 10 minutes for PR CI).
3. **Align with Ruleset protections** by supplying named checks that can be marked as _required_.
4. **Do not publish artifacts or releases** from PRs. Releases remain on `push` to `main` via existing release workflows.

---

## Scope
- Add a new workflow: `.github/workflows/ci.yml`.
- Run on `pull_request` to `main` (and optionally on `push` to `main` for visibility).
- Include the following validation steps:
  - **Lint**
  - **Type check**
  - **Build**
  - **Unit tests**
  - (Optional) **Dependency audit**, **Prettier check**, **Size limit**

- Expose each validation as a **separate job** so they appear as distinct checks in the Ruleset.
- Keep the CI **idempotent and safe** (no publishing, no environment mutations).

Out of scope: release automation, deployment, environment provisioning.

---

## Acceptance Criteria
- A new workflow file exists at `.github/workflows/ci.yml`.
- Opening a PR against `main` triggers the workflow.
- The workflow publishes the following check names (jobs):
  - `lint`
  - `typecheck`
  - `build`
  - `test`
  - (optional) `audit`
- The repository’s Ruleset for `main` has **Require status checks to pass** enabled and includes the above jobs as **required checks**.
- **Require branches to be up to date before merging** is enabled in the Ruleset.
- The workflow completes in **≤ 10 minutes** under typical loads.
- The workflow does **not** publish or release anything on PRs.

---

## Design & Implementation Details

### Triggers
- `pull_request` → `branches: [ main ]`
- Optional: `push` to `main` for post-merge visibility.

### Permissions
Use least privilege for Actions:
```yaml
permissions:
  contents: read
```

### Caching
- Use built-in `actions/setup-*` caching where possible.
- Prefer `npm ci` / `pnpm install --frozen-lockfile` to ensure deterministic installs.

### Monorepo Considerations
- If the project uses `packages/core` and `packages/cli`, run commands with `--workspaces` or set `working-directory` per job.
- Optionally scope workflow with `paths` to avoid running on docs-only changes.

### Naming
The **job id** becomes the **status check name** in the Ruleset. Use concise, stable ids:
- `lint`, `typecheck`, `build`, `test`, `audit`

### Example Workflow (Node.js / TypeScript, workspaces-friendly)
```yaml
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: CI

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main ]
    # Optionally restrict files that trigger CI:
    # paths: [ "packages/**", ".github/workflows/ci.yml" ]
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

concurrency:
  group: ci-${{ github.ref }}
  cancel-in-progress: true

permissions:
  contents: read

jobs:
  lint:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run lint --workspaces --if-present
      - run: npx prettier --check .

  typecheck:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npx tsc --noEmit || npx tsc -b --noEmit

  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: [lint, typecheck]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm run build --workspaces --if-present
      - uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: dist
          path: |
            packages/**/dist
            !**/node_modules/**

  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci
      - run: npm test --workspaces --if-present -- --ci --reporters=default
      # - run: npm test -- --coverage  # enable if you want coverage reports

  audit:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20
          cache: npm
      - run: npm ci --omit=dev
      - run: npm audit --audit-level=high
```

> Adapt commands to your package manager (`npm`, `pnpm`, `yarn`) and project structure. If some scripts are missing, remove those steps or add scripts in `package.json` (e.g., `lint`, `build`, `test`).

### Paths Optimization (optional)
If the repo has docs or non-code folders, restrict triggers to relevant paths:
```yaml
on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main ]
    paths: [ "packages/**", ".github/workflows/ci.yml" ]
```

### Secrets
This CI design **does not require secrets**. If tests need secrets, use repository or environment secrets and **do not** mark that job as required until secrets are stable.

### Artifacts
Artifacts (e.g., `dist/`) are uploaded for debugging; they are not released. Retention can be lowered to save storage.

---

## Ruleset Integration (Branch Protection)

In the Ruleset that targets `main`, ensure:
- **Require a pull request before merging** → enabled (with at least 1 approval).
- **Require status checks to pass** → enabled.
- **Require branches to be up to date before merging** → enabled.
- Select required checks: `lint`, `typecheck`, `build`, `test` (optionally `audit`).
- **Block force pushes** and **Restrict deletions** → enabled.
- **Require linear history** and **Require signed commits** → enabled per your policy.
- Allow only **Squash** and **Rebase** merge methods for a clean history.

---

## Rollout Plan
1. Create the workflow in a short-lived branch (`ci/bootstrap-ci`).
2. Open a PR → confirm checks run and finish within the target time.
3. Add the checks as **required** in the Ruleset (once they’re green).
4. Merge the PR.
5. Monitor subsequent PRs for false positives or performance issues.
6. Iterate: add/remove optional checks (e.g., `audit`, `sizelimit`).

---

## Risks & Mitigations
- **Slow CI**: Keep jobs parallel, cache dependencies, limit paths.
- **Flaky tests**: Start with unit tests; quarantine flaky suites.
- **Overly strict audit**: Start non-blocking; later make it required.
- **Missing scripts**: Add minimal `lint`, `build`, `test` scripts in `package.json`.

---

## Metrics / Success Criteria
- Median PR CI duration **≤ 10 minutes**.
- 100% of merged PRs have all required checks green.
- Zero unintended releases from PR pipelines.
- Reduced post-merge failures on `main` (track incidents/regressions).

---

## Definition of Done
- `.github/workflows/ci.yml` present and running on PRs.
- Ruleset updated with selected jobs as required checks.
- Documentation (this file) linked in the governance system/task.
- Example PR demonstrating green checks.

---

## Governance Task Creation (example)

**Title**: Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for `main`  
**Priority**: High  
**Tags**: `ci`, `quality`, `governance`

### Create via CLI (using a temp file in /tmp)
```bash
cat > /tmp/ci-task.md << 'EOF'
# (Paste this whole document content here)
EOF

gitgov task new "Establish PR CI pipeline and required checks for main" \
  --description-file /tmp/ci-task.md \
  --priority high \
  --tags ci,quality,governance \
  --cleanup-file

# Then follow workflow:
gitgov task submit <task-id>    # send for review
gitgov task approve <task-id>   # approve definition
gitgov task activate <task-id>  # start implementation
```

# Remove Kiro-related Files and References

## Summary
Clean up the monorepo by removing all Kiro-related files, directories, and references that are no longer needed for the GitGovernance project.

## Background
Kiro was a previous iteration or companion tool that is no longer part of the GitGovernance ecosystem. The `.kiro/` directory and various references throughout the codebase should be removed to:
- Reduce repository clutter
- Prevent confusion for new contributors
- Maintain focus on GitGovernance core functionality
- Clean up historical artifacts

## Scope

### Files to Remove
1. **`.kiro/` directory** (entire directory tree)
   - `.kiro/hooks/` - All hook files and documentation
   - `.kiro/specs/` - All specification files
   - `.kiro/steering/` - All steering documents

2. **References in documentation/blueprints** (case-insensitive search)
   - Files mentioning "kiro" in `packages/blueprints/`
   - Files mentioning "kiro" in other documentation

### What NOT to Remove
- Any Kiro references that are purely historical context in changelogs
- Any third-party dependencies or libraries that happen to contain "kiro" in their name

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All `.kiro/` directories and files are deleted
- [ ] `git status` shows no untracked Kiro-related files
- [ ] Repository builds successfully after cleanup
- [ ] No linter errors introduced by removal
- [ ] `.gitignore` does not need Kiro-specific entries (or they are removed)

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Remove `.kiro/` directory
```bash
git rm -rf .kiro/
```

### Step 2: Review blueprint references (optional)
- Scan `packages/blueprints/` for Kiro references

- Note: Most blueprint references are likely historical and can remain

```bash
pnpm build --workspaces
pnpm test --workspaces
```

```bash
git add -A

- Remove .kiro/ directory (hooks, specs, steering)
- Clean up legacy tooling artifacts
- No functional changes to GitGovernance core"
```

## Risks & Mitigations
- **Risk**: Accidentally removing needed files
  - **Mitigation**: Use `git rm` so changes are tracked and reversible

- Changes committed and merged to `main`

enrichedTasks.title: Rename types/ directory to models/ for improved semantic clarity
enrichedTasks.description:
# Rename types/ Directory to models/ for Improved Semantic Clarity

## Context

The `packages/core/src/types/` directory contains TypeScript type definitions and data models for GitGovernance records (TaskRecord, ActorRecord, CycleRecord, etc.). While functional, the name "types" is ambiguous and doesn't clearly convey that these are **domain data models**.

## Problem

1. **Semantic Ambiguity**: "types" could mean generic TypeScript utility types vs. domain models
2. **Industry Convention**: Most frameworks use "models" (Django, Rails, NestJS, Laravel)
3. **Confusion with schemas/**: Not immediately clear that `types/` = compile-time, `schemas/` = runtime
4. **Onboarding Friction**: New developers need extra context to understand the distinction

## Solution

Rename `packages/core/src/types/` → `packages/core/src/models/` with cascading import updates.

### Files to Rename
- `types/` → `models/`
- `types/index.ts` → `models/index.ts`
- `types/common.types.ts` → `models/common.models.ts`
- `types/embedded.types.ts` → `models/embedded.models.ts`
- `types/generated/` → `models/generated/` (keep filenames: `*_record.ts`)

### Import Updates Required

Update all imports across codebase:
```typescript
// Before
import { TaskRecord } from '../types';
import type { EmbeddedMetadataRecord } from '../types/embedded.types';

// After
import { TaskRecord } from '../models';
import type { EmbeddedMetadataRecord } from '../models/embedded.models';
```

**Affected Directories:**
- `packages/core/src/adapters/`
- `packages/core/src/validation/`
- `packages/core/src/schemas/`
- `packages/core/src/store/`
- `packages/core/src/factories/`
- `packages/core/src/utils/` (when signature_utils.ts is added)
- Any tests importing from types/

### Export Updates

Update main export in `packages/core/src/index.ts`:
```typescript
// Before
export * from './types';

// After
export * from './models';
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Directory renamed: `types/` → `models/`
- [ ] Files renamed: `*.types.ts` → `*.models.ts`
- [ ] All imports updated across entire `packages/core/`
- [ ] All tests pass (no broken imports)
- [ ] Build succeeds (`pnpm build` in core/)
- [ ] Type checking passes (`pnpm typecheck`)
- [ ] No references to old "types/" path remain

## Testing Strategy

1. **Static Analysis**: `grep -r "from.*types" packages/core/src/` should return 0 results
2. **Build Test**: `cd packages/core && pnpm build` must succeed
3. **Type Check**: `pnpm typecheck` must pass
4. **Unit Tests**: `pnpm test` must pass all existing tests

## Impact Assessment

**Pros:**
- ✅ Improved semantic clarity (models = domain data structures)
- ✅ Aligns with industry conventions
- ✅ Easier onboarding for new developers
- ✅ Clearer separation from schemas/ and validation/

**Cons:**
- ⚠️  30 minutes of refactoring work
- ⚠️  Git history shows rename (but trackable with `git log --follow`)

**Risk: LOW** - Pure refactoring, no logic changes

## Technical Notes

enrichedTasks.title: Add load() validation methods to Record Factories
enrichedTasks.description:
# Add load() validation methods to Record Factories

## Problem

Currently, `RecordStore.read()` uses unsafe type assertions without validation:

```typescript
// packages/core/src/store/record_store.ts:58
const record = JSON.parse(content) as GitGovRecord & { payload: T };
return record; // ❌ TYPE ASSERTION, NOT VALIDATION
```

This causes runtime crashes when reading files with invalid/corrupted schemas (e.g., missing `relatedTasks` in changelogs).

**Current architecture:**
- ✅ **CREATE**: Factories validate using `validateXRecordDetailed()` 
- ❌ **READ**: RecordStore does NOT validate (just casts)

This gap caused indexer crash: `Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'includes')` when changelog files lacked `relatedTasks` field.

## Solution

Implement **Hydration Pattern** with `load()` methods in factories:

1. **Factory** provides validation logic via `loadXRecord(data: unknown): XRecord`
2. **RecordStore** receives loader as dependency and uses it in `read()`
3. **Adapters** pass loaders when constructing RecordStores

**Benefits:**
- Centralized validation in factories (create + load)
- RecordStore remains generic
- Type-safe data loading
- Early detection of schema violations

---

## Implementation Steps

### **Phase 1: Add load() methods to factories**

Create `loadXRecord()` functions in all factories:

**Files to update:**
- `packages/core/src/factories/task_factory.ts`
- `packages/core/src/factories/cycle_factory.ts`
- `packages/core/src/factories/changelog_factory.ts`
- `packages/core/src/factories/feedback_factory.ts`
- `packages/core/src/factories/execution_factory.ts`
- `packages/core/src/factories/actor_factory.ts`

**Pattern:**
```typescript
// Example: packages/core/src/factories/task_factory.ts

export function loadTaskRecord(data: unknown): TaskRecord {
  const validation = validateTaskRecordDetailed(data);
  if (!validation.isValid) {
    throw new DetailedValidationError('TaskRecord', validation.errors);
  }
  return data as TaskRecord;
}
```

### **Phase 2: Update RecordStore to accept loader**

**File:** `packages/core/src/store/record_store.ts`

**Changes:**
1. Add `loader` parameter to constructor:
```typescript
constructor(
  recordType: string,
  private loader: (data: unknown) => T,  // NEW
  rootPath?: string,
  fsDeps: FsDependencies = fs
)
```

2. Use loader in `read()` method:
```typescript
async read(recordId: string): Promise<(GitGovRecord & { payload: T }) | null> {
  const content = await this.fs.readFile(filePath, 'utf-8');
  const raw = JSON.parse(content);
  
  // Validate payload using loader
  try {
    const payload = this.loader(raw.payload);
    return { header: raw.header, payload };
  } catch (error) {
    console.warn(`⚠️  Invalid record ${recordId}:`, error);
    return null; // Skip invalid records
  }
}
```

### **Phase 3: Update all adapters to pass loaders**

**Files to update:**
- `packages/core/src/adapters/backlog_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/core/src/adapters/changelog_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/core/src/adapters/execution_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/index.ts`
- `packages/core/src/adapters/identity_adapter/index.ts`

**Pattern:**
```typescript
// Example: backlog_adapter/index.ts

import { loadTaskRecord } from '../factories/task_factory';
import { loadCycleRecord } from '../factories/cycle_factory';

constructor(dependencies: BacklogAdapterDependencies) {
  this.taskStore = new RecordStore<TaskRecord>(
    'tasks',
    loadTaskRecord,  // ← Pass loader
    rootPath
  );
  
  this.cycleStore = new RecordStore<CycleRecord>(
    'cycles',
    loadCycleRecord,  // ← Pass loader
    rootPath
  );
}
```

### **Phase 4: Add integration tests**

**New file:** `packages/core/src/store/record_store.integration.test.ts`

**Tests:**
1. Read valid record → should succeed
2. Read invalid record (missing required field) → should return null + warn
3. Read corrupted JSON → should handle gracefully
4. Read record with schema violation → should detect and warn

**New file:** `packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/indexer_adapter.integration.test.ts`

**Tests:**
1. Index generation with real `.gitgov/` files
2. Invalid changelogs → should be skipped with warnings
3. Invalid tasks → should be filtered out
4. System should NOT crash on schema violations

---

## Acceptance Criteria

✅ **Phase 1:** All 6 factories have `loadXRecord()` methods with validation  
✅ **Phase 2:** RecordStore.read() validates using loader  
✅ **Phase 3:** All 6 adapters pass loaders to RecordStores  
✅ **Phase 4:** 8+ integration tests passing  
✅ **Result:** `gitgov indexer` runs without crashes on invalid data  
✅ **Result:** Console shows warnings for invalid records (not silent failures)  
✅ **Result:** All existing tests still pass  

---

## Files to Modify

**Factories (6 files):**
- packages/core/src/factories/task_factory.ts
- packages/core/src/factories/cycle_factory.ts
- packages/core/src/factories/changelog_factory.ts
- packages/core/src/factories/feedback_factory.ts
- packages/core/src/factories/execution_factory.ts
- packages/core/src/factories/actor_factory.ts

**Core (1 file):**
- packages/core/src/store/record_store.ts

**Adapters (6 files):**
- packages/core/src/adapters/backlog_adapter/index.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/changelog_adapter/index.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/feedback_adapter/index.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/execution_adapter/index.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/index.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/identity_adapter/index.ts

**Tests (2 new files):**
- packages/core/src/store/record_store.integration.test.ts
- packages/core/src/adapters/indexer_adapter/indexer_adapter.integration.test.ts

# Agent Platform: Event-Driven Blueprint Auditing System

## 🎯 Contexto

Crear un **sistema de agentes especializados** que auditen blueprints automáticamente usando los estándares v2 (cli_designer_v2.md, module_designer_v2.md), reaccionando a FeedbackRecords del protocolo GitGovernance.

**Valor:**
- ✅ Automatiza auditoría de blueprints (manual → <2 minutos)
- ✅ Aplica 5 criterios objetivos consistentemente
- ✅ Usa protocolo existente (FeedbackRecord + AgentRecord)
- ✅ Extensible para futuros agentes especializados

---

## 📋 Problema

**Estado Actual:** Review manual de blueprints toma 30-60 minutos, inconsistente entre reviewers.

**Estado Deseado:** 
1. Humano crea FeedbackRecord: `"Audita blueprint X"`
2. AgentWatcher detecta feedback asignado a `agent:cli-designer`
3. Agente ejecuta auditoría automática (5 criterios)
4. Genera reporte con scoring (X.X/10) y gaps
5. Crea FeedbackRecord respuesta
6. **Tiempo: <2 minutos**

---

## 🏗️ Arquitectura

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────┐
│   GitGovernance Agent Platform          │
├─────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  1. AgentWatcher (chokidar event loop) │
│     └─ Detecta FeedbackRecords          │
│                                          │
│  2. AgentDispatcher (router)            │
│     └─ Busca AgentRecords matching      │
│     └─ Ensambla context + knowledge     │
│                                          │
│  3. LocalRunner (execution)             │
│     └─ Dynamic import agentes TS        │
│                                          │
│  4. Agents (cli-designer, module)       │
│     └─ Ejecuta auditoría con LLM        │
│     └─ Genera FeedbackRecord respuesta  │
│                                          │
│  5. Integration (OpenCode/Anthropic)    │
└─────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Flujo:**
```
FeedbackRecord (assignee: agent:cli-designer)
    ↓
AgentWatcher detecta → Busca AgentRecord
    ↓
AgentRecord.triggers matchea "feedback.created"
    ↓
LocalRunner ejecuta con knowledge_dependencies
    ↓
Agente audita + genera reporte
    ↓
Crea FeedbackRecord con resultado
```

---

## 🎯 Alcance Fase 1 (MVP)

### **Entregables:**

1. **AgentWatcher** (`packages/platform/src/orchestrator/agent-watcher.ts`)
   - Monitor `.gitgov/feedback/` con chokidar
   - Trigger detection + dispatch

2. **AgentDispatcher** (`packages/platform/src/orchestrator/agent-dispatcher.ts`)
   - Registry de agentes
   - Blueprint path extraction
   - Context assembly

3. **LocalRunner** (`packages/platform/src/orchestrator/runners/local-runner.ts`)
   - Dynamic import TypeScript agents
   - Error handling + timeouts

4. **CLI Designer Agent** (`packages/platform/src/agents/cli-designer/cli-designer.ts`)
   - Auditoría con 5 criterios
   - Integración OpenCode/Anthropic
   - Generación FeedbackRecord

5. **CLI Command** (`gitgov agent watch`)
   - Inicia watcher
   - Daemon mode
   - Logging

6. **AgentRecord Manifests**
   - `.gitgov/agents/agent-cli-designer.json`
   - `.gitgov/agents/agent-module-designer.json`

### **Criterios de Éxito:**

- ✅ Usuario crea FeedbackRecord con assignee agente
- ✅ Watcher detecta automáticamente
- ✅ Auditoría completa en <2 minutos
- ✅ Reporte con scoring X.X/10
- ✅ Sistema 100% local (sin cloud)

### **NO Incluido Fase 1:**

- ❌ APIRunner / MCPRunner
- ❌ Docker/GCP deployment
- ❌ Multi-agent workflows
- ❌ Scheduling (cron)

---

## 🔧 Implementación

### **AgentRecord Manifest Ejemplo:**

```json
{
  "id": "agent:cli-designer",
  "status": "active",
  "triggers": [{
    "type": "webhook",
    "event": "feedback.created",
    "filter": {
      "assignee": "agent:cli-designer",
      "type": ["assignment", "question"]
    }
  }],
  "knowledge_dependencies": [
    "packages/blueprints/02_agents/design/cli_designer_v2.md",
    "packages/blueprints/03_products/cli/specs/**/*.md"
  ],
  "engine": {
    "type": "local",
    "runtime": "typescript",
    "entrypoint": "packages/platform/src/agents/cli-designer/cli-designer.ts",
    "function": "auditBlueprint"
  },
  "metadata": {
    "framework": "opencode",
    "model": "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022",
    "audit_criteria": 5,
    "min_score_threshold": 9.0
  }
}
```

### **CLI Designer Agent:**

```typescript
export async function auditBlueprint(context: FullAgentContext): Promise<AgentResult> {
  // 1. Extraer blueprint path del feedback
  const blueprintPath = extractBlueprintPath(context.feedback.payload.content);
  
  // 2. Leer blueprint + agent prompt
  const blueprintContent = await readFile(blueprintPath);
  const agentPrompt = context.knowledge['cli_designer_v2.md'];
  
  // 3. Ejecutar auditoría con LLM (OpenCode o Anthropic)
  const auditReport = await runAuditWithLLM({
    agentPrompt,
    blueprint: blueprintContent,
    model: context.metadata.model
  });
  
  // 4. Parsear scoring
  const score = extractScore(auditReport); // → 9.2
  
  // 5. Crear FeedbackRecord respuesta
  await feedbackAdapter.create({
    entityType: 'feedback',
    entityId: context.feedback.header.id,
    type: score >= 9.0 ? 'approval' : 'suggestion',
    status: score >= 9.0 ? 'resolved' : 'open',
    content: auditReport,
    resolvesFeedbackId: context.feedback.header.id
  }, 'agent:cli-designer');
  
  return { success: true, output: auditReport };
}
```

---

## 📐 Arquitectura de Archivos

```
packages/
├── platform/                    # ← NUEVO
│   ├── src/
│   │   ├── orchestrator/
│   │   │   ├── agent-watcher.ts
│   │   │   ├── agent-dispatcher.ts
│   │   │   ├── local-agent-orchestrator.ts
│   │   │   └── runners/

│   │   ├── agents/
│   │   │   ├── cli-designer/

│   │   │   │   └── manifest.json
│   │   │   └── module-designer/
│   │   │       ├── module-designer.ts
│   │   │       └── manifest.json
│   │   └── integrations/
│   │       ├── opencode.ts
│   │       └── anthropic.ts
│   └── package.json
│
└── cli/src/commands/agent/      # ← NUEVO
    ├── agent-command.ts
    ├── watch.ts
    ├── list.ts
    └── show.ts
```

---

## 🎯 Plan Implementación

### **Sprint 1: Fundamentos (Semana 1)**
1. Setup package @gitgov/platform
2. AgentWatcher básico (chokidar)
3. AgentDispatcher (registry + routing)

**Deliverables:** Watcher detecta FeedbackRecords

**Deliverables:** Runner ejecuta agentes TypeScript

---

## 📊 Métricas de Éxito

|---------|--------|

| **Precisión scoring** | ±0.5 vs manual |
| **Test coverage** | >80% |

# Implement Lint Module + Command for Structural Validation (Quality Model Layer 1)

## 🎯 Problem

**Current:** Schema changes → 47 legacy JSONs → `gitgov dashboard` crashes
**Impact:** No systematic validation, no migration path, dashboard failures

## 💡 Solution

**Reusable `lint_module`** in `@gitgov/core` for CLI, SDK, SaaS, MCP, CI/CD

### Architecture (Delegation Pattern)

- `lint_module` → `recordStore.read()` → loaders validate (schema + embedded metadata + checksums)
- `lint_module` captures errors + adds validations (conventions, references, schema version detection)
- **Aligned with:** `checksum.ts` (canonical JSON), `signatures.ts` (`keyId`), `common.types.ts`, `embedded.types.ts`

## 📦 Deliverables

### 1. Core Module: `packages/core/src/modules/lint_module/`

```typescript
export class LintModule {
  constructor(deps: { validatorModule, recordStore, indexerModule?, cryptoModule? })
  async lint(options: LintOptions): Promise<LintReport>
  async lintFile(path: string): Promise<LintResult>
  async fix(report: LintReport, fixOptions: FixOptions): Promise<FixReport>
}
```

### 2. Blueprints (✅ COMPLETED)

- `lint_module.md`: 33 EARS, Mermaid diagram, Migration Workflow, Performance targets
- `lint_command.md`: 9 CLI EARS, `--check-migrations`, `--fix`, CI/CD patterns

### 3. CLI Command: `packages/cli/src/commands/tools/lint.ts`

```bash
gitgov lint                      # Validate all
gitgov lint --check-migrations   # List obsolete records (detection only)
gitgov lint --fix                # Auto-repair with backups
gitgov lint --format json        # CI/CD output
```

## 🔧 Key Features

### Validation (33 EARS)

- **EARS 1-3:** Init with graceful degradation
- **EARS 4-8:** Delegate to `recordStore.read()`
- **EARS 9-12:** Store validates schema + embedded metadata
- **EARS 13-16:** Lint validates conventions (file naming, timestamps)
- **EARS 17-22:** Lint validates references (optional, requires `indexerModule`)
- **EARS 23-26:** Auto-fix (legacy normalization, bidirectional sync)
- **EARS 27-29:** Performance (<2s for 100 records)
- **EARS 30-32:** Error handling + backup restoration
- **EARS-33:** Schema version detection (NEW)

### Auto-Fix Implementation

```typescript
async fixLegacyRecord(result, fixOptions) {
  const raw = JSON.parse(await fs.readFile(result.filePath));
  
  // 1. Wrap in embedded metadata
  const wrapped = { header: {...}, payload: raw };
  
  // 2. Migrate deprecated fields
  wrapped.payload = await this.migrateDeprecatedFields(wrapped.payload);
  
  // 3. Calculate checksum (SHA256 canonical JSON)
  wrapped.header.payloadChecksum = calculatePayloadChecksum(wrapped.payload);
  
  // 4. Sign with keyId (not actorId)
  const sig = signPayload(wrapped.payload, privateKey, fixOptions.keyId, 'system:migrator', 'Auto-migration');
  wrapped.header.signatures.push(sig);
  
  // 5. Backup original
  await fs.writeFile(`${result.filePath}.pre-migration`, JSON.stringify(raw, null, 2));
  await fs.writeFile(result.filePath, JSON.stringify(wrapped, null, 2));
}
```

### Migration Workflow (Solves Real Problem)

```bash
# 1. Detect
$ gitgov lint --check-migrations
[INFO] 47 records obsoletos: 23 tasks, 15 cycles, 9 executions

# 2. Backup
$ cp -r .gitgov/ .gitgov.backup-$(date +%Y%m%d)

# 3. Fix
$ gitgov lint --fix
[INFO] ✅ 47 fixes aplicados, 0 fallidos

# 4. Verify
$ gitgov lint --references --actors
[INFO] ✅ 0 errores

# 5. Works
$ gitgov dashboard
✅ Success
```

## 🧪 Testing

- **Unit:** 33/33 EARS in `lint_module.test.ts`
- **Integration:** CLI with valid/invalid records, `--fix`, `--check-migrations`
- **Target:** 100% EARS coverage, 90%+ code coverage

## 📚 Dependencies

**Code:**
- `packages/core/src/crypto/checksum.ts` - `calculatePayloadChecksum()` with `sortKeys()`
- `packages/core/src/crypto/signatures.ts` - `signPayload(keyId, ...)`
- `packages/core/src/types/common.types.ts`, `embedded.types.ts`
- `packages/core/src/store/record_store.ts` - Validation via `read()`

**Blueprints:**
- `quality_model.md` - Layer 1 definition
- `module_designer_v2.md` - Module design standard
- `lint_module.md`, `lint_command.md` (✅ COMPLETED)

## 🎯 Success Criteria

**Must Have:**
- ✅ Core module with `lint()`, `lintFile()`, `fix()`
- ✅ Constructor with graceful degradation
- ✅ Auto-fix with `signPayload()` using `keyId`
- ✅ Backup/restore mechanism
- ✅ CLI with `--check-migrations` and `--fix`
- ✅ 33 module EARS + 9 CLI EARS tested
- ✅ Blueprints completed

**Nice to Have (Future):**
- ⏱️ Dashboard streaming validation
- ⏱️ Pre-commit hook template

## 🚀 Implementation Plan

1. **Core Module Structure** (1h): Create files, define interfaces with JSDoc
2. **Core Logic** (3h): `lint()`, `lintFile()`, validators
3. **Auto-Fix** (2h): `fix()`, `fixLegacyRecord()`, backup/restore
4. **Tests** (2h): 33 EARS as test cases
5. **CLI** (1h): Thin wrapper, `--check-migrations`, `--fix`
6. **Integration** (1h): Test with 47 legacy records scenario

**Total:** 10-12 hours

## 💼 Business Value

- ✅ **Prevents dashboard crashes** (REAL PROBLEM: 47 JSONs → crash)
- ✅ **Safe schema migrations** with auto-fix + backups
- ✅ **CI/CD validation** with exit codes
- ✅ **Reusable** in CLI, SDK, SaaS, MCP, Dashboard
- ✅ **Quality Model Layer 1** complete

## 🔗 Context

**Why Canonical JSON?** Deterministic serialization for reproducible checksums (uses `sortKeys()` from `checksum.ts`)

**Why `keyId` not `actorId`?** Aligns with `signPayload()` parameter in `signatures.ts` and `Signature` type field

**Why Delegation?** Loaders already validate schema/checksums/signatures. Lint captures errors + adds new validations (conventions, references, schema detection).

---

**Priority:** High (blocks work, prevents crashes)
**Complexity:** Medium (reuses infrastructure, clear requirements)
**Status:** Draft → Ready (blueprints complete, architecture validated)

enrichedTasks.title: Implement JSON Schemas and Validators for Config/Session
enrichedTasks.description:
# Implementar JSON Schemas y Validators para Config/Session

## 📋 Contexto

Los archivos `config.json` y `.session.json` están documentados en:
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/99_appendices/config_file.md`
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/99_appendices/session_state.md`

Sin embargo, **NO existen los JSON Schemas físicos** ni los validators TypeScript que permitan:
1. Validar estructura de config/session al cargar
2. Detectar configuraciones inválidas o corrompidas
3. Proveer type guards y validación detallada
4. Consumir estos schemas desde otros módulos (ej: SyncModule)

El `ConfigManager` actualmente tiene métodos `validateConfig()` y `migrateConfig()` marcados como **FALTANTES** (ver `config_session_module.md` líneas 31-32).

## 🎯 Objetivo

Crear la infraestructura completa de JSON Schemas y validators para config/session siguiendo el patrón establecido en `validator_module.md`.

## 📦 Entregables

### 1. JSON Schemas (Source of Truth)

**Archivos a crear:**

```
packages/core/src/schemas/config_schema.json
packages/core/src/schemas/session_state_schema.json
```

**Estructura de `config_schema.json`:**
- Validar todos los campos de `config.json` según `config_file.md`
- Campos obligatorios: `protocolVersion`, `projectId`, `projectName`, `rootCycle`
- Sección `state.branch` (obligatorio: `"gitgov-state"`)
- Sección `state.sync` con validación de strategy, maxRetries, intervals
- Sección `state.defaults` para pullScheduler y fileWatcher
- Validaciones:
  - `protocolVersion` debe ser semver válido
  - `strategy` enum: `["manual", "immediate", "batched"]`
  - `maxRetries`: integer 1-10
  - `pushIntervalSeconds`: integer 10-3600
  - `batchIntervalSeconds`: integer 30-600

**Estructura de `session_state_schema.json`:**
- Validar todos los campos de `.session.json` según `session_state.md`
- Sección `cloud` con `sessionToken` (string, opcional)
- Sección `lastSession` con `actorId` y `timestamp` ISO 8601
- Sección `actorState` (objeto dinámico por actor):
  - `activeTaskId` (string, opcional)
  - `activeCycleId` (string, opcional)
  - `syncStatus` (opcional):
    - `lastSyncPush` (ISO 8601, opcional)
    - `lastSyncPull` (ISO 8601, opcional)
    - `status` enum: `["synced", "pending", "conflict"]`
- Sección `syncPreferences` (opcional):
  - `pullScheduler` con enabled, pullIntervalSeconds, etc.
  - `fileWatcher` con enabled, debounceMs, ignoredPatterns

### 2. TypeScript Validators (Siguiendo patrón de `validator_module.md`)

**Archivos a crear:**

```
packages/core/src/validation/config_validator.ts
packages/core/src/validation/session_state_validator.ts
```

**Cada validator debe implementar:**

```typescript
// Patrón estándar de validator_module.md

// 1. Type Guards
export function isGitGovConfig(obj: unknown): obj is GitGovConfig;
export function isGitGovSession(obj: unknown): obj is GitGovSession;

// 2. Schema Validation (AJV raw errors)
export function validateConfigSchema(
  data: unknown
): [boolean, ValidateFunction['errors']];

export function validateSessionStateSchema(
  data: unknown
): [boolean, ValidateFunction['errors']];

// 3. Detailed Validation (formatted errors for UX)
export function validateConfigDetailed(data: unknown): {
  isValid: boolean;
  errors: FormattedError[];
};

export function validateSessionStateDetailed(data: unknown): {
  isValid: boolean;
  errors: FormattedError[];
};
```

**Integración con SchemaValidationCache:**
- Usar `SchemaValidationCache.getValidatorFromSchema()` para obtener validators compilados
- Cacheo automático para performance (no recompilar en cada validación)
- Seguir patrón de `actor_validator.ts`, `task_validator.ts`, etc.

### 3. Actualizar ConfigManager

**Archivo a modificar:**
```
packages/core/src/config/index.ts
```

**Métodos a implementar:**

```typescript
// ConfigManager class

/**
 * Valida configuración completa contra schema
 * @throws {DetailedValidationError} si configuración es inválida
 */
async validateConfig(): Promise<void> {
  const config = await this.loadConfig();
  if (!config) {
    throw new Error('Config file not found');
  }
  
  const result = validateConfigDetailed(config);
  if (!result.isValid) {
    throw new DetailedValidationError(
      'Invalid config.json structure',
      result.errors
    );
  }
}

/**
 * Valida session state contra schema
 * @throws {DetailedValidationError} si session es inválida
 */
async validateSession(): Promise<void> {
  const session = await this.loadSession();
  if (!session) {
    throw new Error('Session file not found');
  }
  
  const result = validateSessionStateDetailed(session);
  if (!result.isValid) {
    throw new DetailedValidationError(
      'Invalid .session.json structure',
      result.errors
    );
  }
}
```

### 4. Tests (Cobertura completa EARS)

**Archivos a crear:**

```
packages/core/src/validation/config_validator.test.ts
packages/core/src/validation/session_state_validator.test.ts
```

**Test cases mínimos (siguiendo EARS de validator_module.md):**

- **[EARS-1]** Schema validation debe fallar con config inválido
- **[EARS-2]** Schema validation debe pasar con config válido
- **[EARS-3]** Type guard debe retornar `true` para válidos
- **[EARS-4]** Type guard debe retornar `false` para inválidos
- **[EARS-5]** validateDetailed debe retornar errores formateados
- **[EARS-6]** validateDetailed debe validar campos opcionales correctamente
- **[EARS-7]** validateDetailed debe validar enums (strategy, status)
- **[EARS-8]** validateDetailed debe validar rangos numéricos (maxRetries, intervals)
- **[EARS-9]** Schema cache debe funcionar correctamente (performance)
- **[EARS-10]** Validación debe fallar con protocolVersion inválido
- **[EARS-11]** Validación debe fallar con campos obligatorios faltantes
- **[EARS-12]** Session state debe validar actorState dinámico correctamente
- **[EARS-13]** syncPreferences debe validar pullScheduler y fileWatcher

**Tests de integración en ConfigManager:**

```
packages/core/src/config/config_manager.test.ts (expandir)
```

- Validar que `validateConfig()` detecta configs corruptos
- Validar que `validateSession()` detecta sessions corruptos
- Validar que `loadConfig()` falla gracefully con config inválido
- Validar que `loadSession()` falla gracefully con session inválido

### 5. Actualizar Interfaces TypeScript

**Archivo a verificar/actualizar:**
```
packages/core/src/types/config.ts
```

Asegurar que interfaces `GitGovConfig` y `GitGovSession` estén 100% alineadas con los JSON Schemas creados.

## 🔗 Referencias Técnicas

**Blueprints:**
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/99_appendices/config_file.md` - Especificación de config.json
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/protocol/99_appendices/session_state.md` - Especificación de .session.json
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/modules/config_session_module.md` - ConfigManager API
- `packages/blueprints/03_products/core/specs/validator_module.md` - Patrón de validación

**Implementación de referencia (copiar patrón):**
- `packages/core/src/validation/actor_validator.ts` - Ejemplo de validator completo
- `packages/core/src/validation/task_validator.ts` - Ejemplo de validator completo
- `packages/core/src/schemas/actor_record_schema.json` - Ejemplo de JSON Schema
- `packages/core/src/schemas/schema_cache.ts` - Cache de validators AJV

## ✅ Criterios de Aceptación

1. ✅ Existen archivos físicos `config_schema.json` y `session_state_schema.json`
2. ✅ JSON Schemas validan 100% de los campos documentados en blueprints
3. ✅ Validators TypeScript implementan las 3 funciones estándar (isType, validateSchema, validateDetailed)
4. ✅ ConfigManager tiene métodos `validateConfig()` y `validateSession()` funcionales
5. ✅ Tests cubren EARS 1-13 con 100% coverage
6. ✅ Schemas usan SchemaValidationCache para performance
7. ✅ Código sigue patrón de validator_module.md (consistencia)
8. ✅ Documentación inline (JSDoc) explica propósito de cada función

## 🚨 Consideraciones Importantes

1. **JSON Schema es SOURCE OF TRUTH:** Interfaces TypeScript se derivan del schema, no al revés
2. **No tocar epic collaboration_system:** Esta task es independiente, los schemas se consumirán después
3. **Seguir patrón existente:** Copiar estructura de `actor_validator.ts`, NO inventar nuevo patrón
4. **Validación estricta:** Mejor fallar con error claro que aceptar config corrupto
5. **Performance:** Usar SchemaValidationCache para evitar recompilación de schemas
6. **Backwards compatibility:** Considerar versionado de schemas para futuras migraciones

## 📊 Impacto Esperado

**Módulos que se beneficiarán:**
- ✅ `ConfigManager` - Validación robusta de config/session
- ✅ `SyncModule` - Consumirá `sync_config_schema.json` (futuro)
- ✅ `CLI init` - Validará config generado al inicializar proyecto
- ✅ `CLI status` - Validará session state antes de mostrar dashboard
- ✅ Todos los módulos que lean config/session

**Problemas que se previenen:**
- ❌ Configs corruptos causando crashes silenciosos
- ❌ Typos en config.json causando comportamiento inesperado
- ❌ Session state inválido causando errores crípticos
- ❌ Falta de validación de rangos numéricos (maxRetries negativo, intervals inválidos)

## 🏁 Resultado Final

Infraestructura completa de validación para config/session que:
1. Sigue patrón establecido de validator_module.md
2. Provee JSON Schemas como SOURCE OF TRUTH
3. Permite consumo desde otros módulos (ej: SyncModule)
4. Mejora robustez del sistema con validación temprana
5. Facilita debugging con errores formateados user-friendly

enrichedTasks.title: Implement GitModule with low-level Git operations
enrichedTasks.description:
Implementar módulo de bajo nivel para **operaciones atómicas Git**: checkout, commit, pull, push, rebase, branchExists, checkoutOrphanBranch, etc.

## ✅ ESTADO: 100% COMPLETO

**Todos los tests pasando:** 47/47 tests ✅ (5.6s)

## 🎯 Objetivo Claro

**git_module = SOLO operaciones atómicas de Git (capa baja)**

Este módulo NO contiene lógica de negocio GitGovernance. Solo proporciona operaciones Git reutilizables.

## ✅ Operaciones Implementadas

**Operaciones de Lectura (EARS 1-18):**
- ✅ `getRepoRoot()`, `getCurrentBranch()`, `getMergeBase()`
- ✅ `getChangedFiles()`, `getFileContent()`, `getCommitHistory()`
- ✅ `getCommitHistoryRange()`, `getCommitMessage()`
- ✅ `hasUncommittedChanges()`, `isRebaseInProgress()`
- ✅ `branchExists()`, `getBranchRemote()`, `getConflictedFiles()`

**Operaciones de Escritura (EARS 19-28):**
- ✅ `init()`, `checkoutBranch()`, `checkoutOrphanBranch()`
- ✅ `fetch()`, `pull()`, `pullRebase()`, `resetHard()`
- ✅ `checkoutFilesFromBranch()`, `add()`, `rm()`

**Operaciones de Commit y Push (EARS 29-36):**
- ✅ `commit()`, `commitAllowEmpty()`, `push()`
- ✅ `pushWithUpstream()`, `setUpstream()`

**Operaciones de Rebase (EARS 37-42):**
- ✅ `rebaseContinue()`, `rebaseAbort()`

## ❌ LO QUE NO VA EN ESTE MÓDULO

- ❌ `ensureStateBranch()` - Esto va en **sync_module** (orquestación de alto nivel)
- ❌ Lógica específica de `gitgov-state` - Eso es responsabilidad de sync_module
- ❌ Auditoría de Records - Eso es responsabilidad de sync_module

## 📐 Arquitectura de Capas

```

  ↓ proporciona 42 EARS (47 tests)
sync_module (PRÓXIMA TASK - 🔴 PENDIENTE)

  ↓   - git.branchExists()
  ↓   - git.checkoutOrphanBranch()
  ↓   - git.commitAllowEmpty()
  ↓   - git.pushWithUpstream()
  ↓   - etc. (11 operaciones atómicas)
```
